item.title: Vinyl Lounge at the MPavilion
item.description:
This December Melbourne vinyl lovers will gather at MPavilion on to enjoy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia's Vinyl Lounge.
Already an institution in Canberra, the Vinyl Lounge sees the NFSA's sound gurus Thorsten Kaeding and Graham McDonald play rare and fascinating records from the national collection, and gives the audience a chance to share (and show off) some of their own vinyl. And it's free!
This will be the second time the National Film and Sound Archive takes its turntables outside of Canberra, following a special sold out session at the Sydney Opera House Studio in October.
Melburnians shouldn't miss this chance to enjoy music the way it was meant to be heard, in the relaxed atmosphere of MPavilion.
MPavilion is a unique architecture commission and design event for Melbourne, initiated by the Naomi Milgrom Foundation with support from City of Melbourne and the Victorian State Government. It is located in the Queen Victoria Gardens, in the centre of the Southbank Arts Precint.

item.title: From the Prom to the Port
item.description:
From the Prom to the Port is an exhibition by well know local Port Albert artist Warren Curry.
The exhibition will showcase Warren's latest Oil Paintings from locations from Wilsons Promontory to Port Albert.
For more information please contact the Port Albert Art Gallery.

item.title: Sticks Sunday Sessions
item.description:
Rock into Sticks Yarra Valley every Sunday over summer and chill out with some cool tunes and a glass of your favourite wine.
Featuring live music on the lawn stage and a gourmet sausage sizzle on the deck, it's the perfect day out.
Entry is free, however please call the cellar door to reserve a table!

item.title: Brimbank Sustainable Living Expo
item.description:
Brimbank Sustainable Living Expo will showcase food, health and wellbeing demonstrations, how to reduce your waste going to landfill, sustainability from garden to plate and how to make gardening a social activity.
Learn from the experts in short DIY sessions, meet native animals and farm babies and see a community garden in full swing. There will be recycled art activities and planting activities for the kids, a clothes swap, a recycled book giveaway and lots of information sessions.

item.title: New Year's Eve at Fed Square
item.description:
Light up and shine this New Year's Eve with a colourful spectacle at Fed Square.
African beats, samba dance, circus acts and neon lights, Fed Square's free New Year's Eve celebrations will be a party to remember. Reflecting the rich cultural diversity of Melbourne, The Square will illuminate in a kaleidoscope of colour and so will you! Wear your brightest colours or crystal whites so you illuminate under a canopy of ultraviolet lights installed exclusively for the celebration.
Experience the big beats of Lamine Sonko and African Intelligence as they guide you through easy dance steps that, on the stroke of midnight, will coalesce in an en-masse dance to their popular track, Light and Shine. The entertainment lineup also includes Sounds of Polynesia, Marawa the Amazing, Ethiopian Circus Trio, Maracatu Estrela do Mar featuring Neda Rahmani and Samba Dancers, Wassawumba and Congo Tardis #1.

image.altText: New Year's Eve at Fed Square
New Year's Eve at Fed Square

item.title: Emerald Hill Festival
item.description:
Multicultural Arts Victoria is thrilled to co-present the Emerald Hill Festival, a free annual one day street party featuring diverse artistic talent, food and activities. The Emerald Hill Festival is organised in collaboration with the creative neighbours in the Emerald Hill precinct in South Melbourne.
The festival spans western classical music to Burundian drumming, Polynesian dance, Japanese Shamisen and everything in between, alongside the opportunity to taste a global feast from a range of Melbourne's iconic food trucks. Adults and children are also invited to participate in a range of art and music activities offered through the day.

item.title: Risky Business- Managing Risk at your events
item.description:
The City of Port Phillip is hosting Risky Business, a free information session. The seminar is aimed at anyone organising an event whether it be big or small event; community event, school fair, sporting or local trader event.
By attending the event seminar you will discover the importance of risk management. Key discussion will include: what is risk, identifying risk, understanding implementing and developing a risk plan, writing an emergency response plan and managing risk in this changing landscape.
This event is free and will be held on Wednesday 19 November at Council Chambers St Kilda Town Hall from 5.30pm to 7.30pm.

address.address1: Corner Carlisle Street and Brighton Road St Kilda

image.altText: Risky Business- Managing Risk at your events
Risky Business- Managing Risk at your events

item.title: Your elibrary (Southbank Library)
item.description:
Let the digital experts at the Southbank Library show you how to use the wonderful digital products on offer at Melbourne Library Service.
Find out about the great range of eBooks, eAudiobooks, eMagazines, Streamed Music and more, all for free. Bring your own device and drop in to the libraries during Knowledge Week.
This event is presented by Melbourne Library Service.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Westgate Park Dawn Bird Chorus
item.description:
Start the day with a walking bird survey of Westgate Park - experience the intense and beautiful dawn bird chorus, and learn from leading experts about the variety of beautiful birds in this park.
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 and help the City of Melbourne to discover the diverse animal and plant species that call the city home.
Over two weeks, from 31 October to 15 November, City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in the city, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl, and they need your help.
You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne's best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
You can also conduct your own surveys at any time in any place from your backyard, balcony, laneway or street by sharing images.
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call your cities home?

item.title: Tongue Between Teeth – Book Launch
item.description:
Jessica Knight's first collection of poetry, 'Tongue Between Teeth', will be welcomed into the world with cheap drinks and homemade cupcakes in the lovely Westspace art gallery.
'Tongue Between Teeth' will be available for purchase on the night and Jessica will be signing copies. Come for the poetry, stay for the cupcakes.
Supported by Creative Partnerships Australia.

item.title: Sunshine on the super il-legitimate
item.description:
This latent action - a work existing but not revealed, hidden. The unsaid, the unsound, the potential for happening that has not yet been discovered. The value of latency is in the ideas you don't realise exist yet and that can't be put into words or even into form. The value of potentiality that remains presently unnaturalised and possibly can't ever be actualised. It's not that I haven't finished the work, just that I haven't started.
Jacqui is a Melbourne based artist and sometimes questions her legitimacy. She has recently had solo shows at West Space and Substation Gallery, and has an upcoming show at BUS Projects. She was included in Moving Pictures/Expanding Space at CareOf in Milan and Experimental Congress at Gertrude Contemporary and will be undertaking residencies at NARS Artist Foundation (New York) and PICA (Perth) in 2015.

item.title: Something Happened
item.description:
Something Happened is a series of documented performances by Melbourne and Perth-based artists Ross Coulter, Hannah Jackson, Tanya Lee and Stuart Ringholt.
These videos capture absurd situations that explore boundaries between discomfort, fear, embarrassment and displacement.
Recalling the absurdist tradition, these works straddle a line between humiliation and humour, depicting actions performed in both public and private settings.

item.title: Small Business & Party Plan Showcase
item.description:
This event is the newest market located in Taylors Lakes, and supports the local small business owners and party plan representatives, both locally and through Melbourne and Surrounds
Stalls Include, Personalized Products, Jewellery, Children's Clothing & Décor, Women's Accessories, Handmade Arts and Crafts, Home Wares and Home Décor, Beauty and Skincare Products, Perfume, Candles & Soaps, Kids party Ideas and Loads More.
And For the Kids there will be a jumping castle, face painting & arts and crafts

item.title: Royal Park Schools BioBlitz
item.description:
Come along to a Royal Park BioBlitz to undertake a variety of surveys including insects, reptiles and plants with our City of Melbourne Park Rangers, Zoos Victoria and other experts.
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz and help discover the diverse animal and plant species that call our city home.
Over two weeks, from 31 October to 15 November, City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in our city, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl, and we need your help.
You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne's best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
You can also conduct your own surveys at any time in any place from your backyard, balcony, laneway or street by sharing images.
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call our cities home?

item.title: Royal Park Dawn Bird Chorus
item.description:
Start the day with an exhilarating walking bird survey of Royal Park. Experience the dawn bird chorus and hear from leading experts on the variety of beautiful birds that visit this park - you'll be surprised and delighted!
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 and help us to discover the diverse animal and plant species that call our city home.
Over two weeks, from 31 October to 15 November, City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in our city, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl, and we need your help.
You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne's best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
You can also conduct your own surveys at any time in any place from your backyard, balcony or laneway or street by sharing images (#bioblitzmelb).
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call our cities home?

item.title: Project Genesis: Hip Hop and Gospel
item.description:
Multicultural Arts Victoria presents Genesis - a sensational line up of young hip hop musicians and gospel singers.
Genesis is the brainchild of Fostin Nshimirimana, from The Movement. For the past six months Fostin has been collaborating with emerging hip hop and gospel artists from Shepparton and Melbourne, uncovering diverse stories from some of their refugee backgrounds and generating new music and new connections between artists in metro Melbourne and regional Victoria.

image.altText: Project Genesis: Hip Hop and Gospel
Project Genesis: Hip Hop and Gospel

item.title: Poppy Crafting Group at Library at The Dock
item.description:
Collaborate with other crafters to help create poppies for the 2015 ANZAC Centenary celebrations at the Melbourne Library Service.
Poppies will be placed on display at all branches as part of the centenary commemoration.
Please bring your preferred crafting materials. Crochet and knitted patterns will be available.
The event wil run on the first Friday of the month from 2pm to 4pm.

item.title: Places for People? Seminar
item.description:
Knowing how a city works as a place for people is crucial to carefully guiding its sustainable growth and ongoing sustainability.
Through urban analysis and in-the-field surveys, Places for People has generated a decade-by-decade snapshot of the conditions defining the public environment and how public space is used by people. This research has allowed Places for People to monitor and examine how the city is changing.
Join them in a seminar where they will share some of the research learnings with you, and where you will gain detailed insights on city-shaping influences as observed by us.
Places are limited so please register your interest.
To become part of our city shaping journey: -Visit the MKW Hub to share your thoughts, and gain a detailed insight on city shaping influences as observed by us. -Share your thoughts online.
This event is presented by City of Melbourne.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

address.address2: and Swanston Street, Melbourne Town Hall

item.title: Nocturnal Insect Bioblitz – Royal Park
item.description:
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 and help the team discover the diverse animal and plant species that call our city home.
Get up close and personal with the nocturnal insects of Royal Park in the darkest late-night biodiversity you'll experience in the city. During these surveys experts will use lights, traps and nets to identify the insects inhabiting the gardens.
Over two weeks from 31 October to 15 November, the City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in our city, from minuscule plant life to the mighty Powerful Owl, and we need your help. You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne's best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
You can also conduct your own surveys at any time in any place from your backyard, balcony or laneway or street by sharing images (#bioblitzmelb)
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call our cities home? Find out more and register at the event website.
Presented by Urban Landscapes at the City of Melbourne.

item.title: Moral Principlism: Formulating Non–Religious Ethics
item.description:
The Atheist Society is hosting a public lecture on 'Moral Principlism: Formulating Non-Religious Ethics' with Dr John Perkins from the Secular Party of Australia at the Unitarian Hall. The lecture will be followed by questions and discussion.
The Atheist Society is for atheists, agnostics and free thinkers who agree to disagree.

item.title: Melbourne BioBlitz at the Knowledge Hub
item.description:
Did you know that Melbourne is home to more than 1,800 plant and over 500 animal species?
From 31 October to 15 November 2014, the City of Melbourne is running their first BioBlitz and they need your help!
During Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 you can help them discover some of the diverse animal and plant species that call the city home. Participants will be able to work alongside experts to discover Melbourne's biodiversity and help them produce a list of species living within the municipality, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl.
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call the city home. Take part by sharing images using the hashtag #bioblitzmelb, online, or by joining a guided BioBlitz event.
At the Melbourne Knowledge Week Hub between 27-31 October, you will be able to talk to the volunteers, find out more information about how to do your own survey and register for one of their events.
The information collected during Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 will inform the City of Melbourne's Urban Ecology Strategy.
This event is presented by City of Melbourne and partners.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

address.address1: Corner Little Collins and Swanston Street

item.title: Marise Maas – Trying Not To Worry
item.description:
Examining Marise Maas' paintings is like peering into a series of little precarious worlds - each bearing the trace of some implicit, destabilising truth. Here, roof tiles are formed from haphazard lines; windows float up and away from their foundational structures; houses teeter on disjointed stilts; electricity pylons and cranes tilt ever so slightly. On a domestic scale, small inert objects such as bowls, take-away containers or coffee cups, stack and tumble off flat slopes of colour, losing any gravitational connection to their once intended utility.
This selection of seemingly mundane motifs in her exhibition Trying Not to Worry holds very real significance for Maas. Informed by what she describes as the bubble of her own local surroundings and domestic family life, the act of painting serves as a kind of diaristic process through which the comprehension, or perhaps apprehension, of daily life takes place.
Items from the kitchen table, backyard or local sports oval all become potential vehicles for the expression of the private logic of her thoughts and fragmentary connections. Honest feelings of anxiety, consternation or whim are allowed to distort the concrete actuality of her subjects, giving rise to a potentially cryptic collection of amusing, somewhat ambiguous narratives.

image.altText: Marise Maas – Trying Not To Worry
Marise Maas – Trying Not To Worry

item.title: Lumen
item.description:
Australia's leading contemporary street artist, Rone, returns to Melbourne for Lumen, his first solo Australian exhibition in over two years.
Lumen includes 11 large-scale portraits inside and outside of the gallery and a 12-metre-high mural on the building's adjoining ventilation tower.
The space itself - an abandoned office building slated for demolition - has been transformed into a black (and blank) canvas for the artist to take over. Internally, the artworks will be brought spectacularly to life by lighting designer, John McKissock.

item.title: Just a Girl
item.description:
This exhibition is a portrayal of the moments in artist Gabrielle Savrone's life where she was uncomfortable or told no, simply because she is female.
Says Gabrielle, 'Abstraction allows the viewer to complete the image in their mind. This brings them into the work with me and creates a moment in time, a completion of the art that does not exist without the viewer'.
This exhibition is a mixed media interactive and visual exploration which combines installation, print and photography as well as acrylic and oil paint.
Gabrielle will donate ten per cent all sales to the Victorian Immigrant and Refugee Women's Coalition.

item.title: Homebuyers Seminar
item.description:
The free Homebuyers Seminar will present professional advice on how to choose the right home for you, the current property market, relevant laws and more. You will have the opportunity to meet and hear from all the experts as they provide an outline of where and how to buy in the Melbourne marketplace.
In addition to experts from the REIV, speakers from Consumer Affairs Victoria and the Law Institute of Victoria will also offer advice tailored to help you buy a home with confidence

item.title: Gallipoli with Peter Fitzsimons
item.description:
The story of the Anzacs at Gallipoli is an important part of Australia's national identity. In the lead-up to the centenary of Anzac, join one of Australia's leading author's Peter FitzSimons as he explores the story of the Anzacs in his new book Gallipoli.
Australia's biggest-selling non-fiction author of the last 10 years, Peter FitzSimons is the author of over 20 books, including Tobruk, Kokoda, Batavia, Mawson and the Ice Men of the Heroic Age, Ned Kelly and biographies of Nancy Wake' Kim Beazley' Nick Farr-Jones' Les Darcy, Steve Waugh and John Eales. He was named a Member of the Order of Australia for his services to literature and the community, and is a journalist with the Sydney Morning Herald and Sun-Herald.

item.title: Forex Trading Workshop
item.description:
While the volatile global market has investors tearing their hair out, Greg Secker will show you why savvy currency traders on the foreign exchange market are making huge profits day after day, no matter whether the markets are rising or falling. Greg is one of the World's leading currency traders and coaches.
In just a couple of hours at his free workshop, Financial Freedom through Forex, he will teach you his secrets to what he believes is. The fastest and easiest way to make a fortune in the world today.
At this free event workshop Greg will teach you:
- How 30 minutes of daily trading can help build a sustainable secondary income Fast - The discipline that means you never risk more than 1% of your capital - 3 simple but incredibly powerful strategies that he uses every day - Why you should be part of the world's largest and most liquid market ($4 trillion a day) - How to automate everything - set up, walk away and collect profits at the end of the day - How trading is something you can do at home or anywhere - How an easy second income can be your primary income - How it's possible to create passive income that makes you money while you sleep - And much more - you choose, the control is in your hands
Secure your free seat now, and set yourself on a course to financial freedom.

item.title: Fitzroy Gardens BioBlitz Discovery!
item.description:
Take a walking tour and discover the resident wildlife, such as reptiles, bugs, bees and butterflies. These surveys will be led by a range of fauna experts from Museum Victoria, the Australian Research Centre for Urban Ecology and RMIT. Jump on a tour leaving on the hour, every hour.
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 and help discover the diverse animal and plant species that call Melbourne city home.
Over two weeks, from 31 October to 15 November, City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in our city, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl, and we need your help.
You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne's best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
You can also conduct your own surveys at any time in any place from your backyard, balcony, laneway or street by sharing images (#bioblitzmelb).
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call our cities home?

item.title: Fitzroy Gardens BioBlitz
item.description:
Take a walking tour and discover the resident wildlife, such as bugs, bees and butterflies. These surveys will be led by a range of fauna experts from Museum Victoria, RMIT and the University of Melbourne. Tours will leave on the hour, every hour until 3pm.
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 and help discover the diverse animal and plant species that call Melbourne home.
Over two weeks, from 31 October to 15 November, City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in our city, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl, and we need your help.
You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne's best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
You can also conduct your own surveys at any time in any place from your backyard, balcony or laneway or street by sharing images (#bioblitzmelb).
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call our cities home?

item.title: Dawn Bird Chorus – BioBlitz
item.description:
Start the day with a walking bird survey of Fitzroy Gardens, experience the dawn bird chorus and hear from leading experts on the variety of beautiful birds that visit our parks.
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 and help us to discover the diverse animal and plant species that call our city home.
Over two weeks, from 31 October to 15 November, City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in our city, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl, and we need your help.
You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne's best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
You can also conduct your own surveys at any time in any place from your backyard, balcony or laneway or street by sharing images (#bioblitzmelb).
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call our cities home?

item.title: Dancing with Death
item.description:
The first in a series of exhibitions presented by 2013 RAW Melbourne Visual Artist of the Year, Rehgan De Mather, Dancing with Death explores influences from recent travels to Mexico and South America, including the Day of the Dead and Carnival.
Opening night features a performance by contemporary dancer Kelly Way and includes the book launch for Dancing with Death, a selection of studio shots and images documenting the progress and process of the new work.

item.title: Cloaked Combat 2, 3
item.description:
The Cloaked Combat series is a visual exploration of the material and technological conflicts between cultures, and the roles they play in one culture asserting dominance over another.
A juxtaposition of historical and modern technologies, Cloaked Combat 2 and 3 highlight an uneven match between two warring cultures, and shows the brutality of European invasion/colonisation in Australia.
Steaphan Paton is an interdisciplinary artist based in Melbourne. A member of the Gunai Nation, his practice explores tradition, race and colonialism informed through his worldview being Aboriginal Australian.

item.title: Christopher Jewitt presents The Lovers
item.description:
Hosted at the Eckersley's Art Store gallery space the exhibition titled 'The Lovers' will have on show various large scale oil paintings, including a 10 metre work.
In this recent series of work Jewitt focuses on concepts of love and sex. Figures are portrayed in bursts of intuitive patterns, limbs are entangled in sprays of colour and movement.
Jewitt suggests a range of human emotions expressed by the human figure, most particularly the invisible but strong bonds between people. He has developed a recognisable style of earthen tones and patterned line work that emphasise the core human drives of connectivity and sexuality.
The event is sponsored by Mountain Goat Brewery and is free to the public.

item.title: BioBlitz Aboriginal Heritage Walk
item.description:
Explore the connection between biodiversity and Australia's Aboriginal people. Journey into the ancestral lands of the Kulin Nation and explore their rich and thriving culture on this walk in the Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne.
Experience a traditional smoking ceremony with an Aboriginal guide and discover traditional uses of plants for food, tools and medicine. While this is usually a paid tour, the BioBlitz tours will be free of charge.
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 and help them to discover the diverse animal and plant species that call Melbourne home.
Over two weeks, from 31 October to 15 November, City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in the city, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl, and they need your help.
You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne's best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
You can also conduct your own surveys at any time in any place from your backyard, balcony, laneway or street by sharing images.
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call Melbourne home?

item.title: BatBlitz
item.description:
Discover the different bat species living in Fitzroy Gardens in this late-night event BatBlitz. During these surveys, experts will use traps and recording devices to identify the different types of bats in the gardens.
Take part in Melbourne BioBlitz 2014 and help scientists to discover the diverse animal and plant species that call Melbourne home.
Over two weeks, from 31 October to 15 November, City of Melbourne will be conducting a survey of the species living in Melbourne, from minuscule plant life to the mighty powerful owl, and they need your help.
You can join a guided BioBlitz event in various locations around the city led by some of Melbourne's best biodiversity experts and ecologists.
You can also conduct your own surveys at any time in any place from your backyard, balcony, laneway or street by sharing images.
Why not gather a group of friends and get out and engage with the wonderful diversity of species that also call your cities home?

item.title: Rohan Wealleans: In Space No One Can Hear You Collect Rocks
item.description:
New Zealand artist Rohan Wealleans creates paintings and sculptures comprised of multitudinous layers of house paint that are then incised to reveal the multi-coloured excavations beneath.
The resulting paint chips generated by this process often become art objects in their own right. For Mailbox, they are presented as specimen-like curiosities, and as body adornments in photographs featuring Wealleans-styled naked alien babes. Part 'geologist', part voyeur, Wealleans always inhabits multiple guises.
Curated by Serena Bentley.
Rohan Wealleans is represented by Ivan Anthony Gallery, Auckland; Hamish McKay Gallery, Wellington and Roslyn Oxley9 Gallery, Sydney.

image.altText: Rohan Wealleans, Freyja, 2011, colour photograph, 143 x 117 cm
Rohan Weallans, Space Rock 1, 2014, Acrylic paint
Rohan Weallans, Space Rock 2, 2014, Acrylic paint
Rohan Weallans, Space Rock 3, 2014, Acrylic paint

item.title: Rotary Docklands Festive of Giving
item.description:
The Rotary Docklands presents the Festival of Giving at Docklands New Quay Promenade. The festival will showcase the heart of business in Docklands, offer multicultural food, dance and entertainment, as well as a 'Show 'n Shine' Car Show featuring over 100 exciting, customised cars.
200 adults and children will take part in a Zumba-thon; with all profits will go to the Royal Children's Hospital.
There will be roaming clowns and stilt walkers, entertainment, free face painting, AFL Games and free AFL merchandise; talented young stars will perform on the stage, there will be a 'laughing yoga' session, discounted pleasure boat rides, discount vouchers to Wonderland and you will be able to wander over and browse through some amazing classic yachts.
Grab a bite of the tasty unique foods at the delicious food stalls. There will be AFL players on hand to show you how to win at handball target and master the kicking tunnel.
There will also be free AFL merchandise and gifts and prizes to take home. In the true Spirit of Giving, Wonderland will offer discounted vouchers to attend their Christmas shows at the Speigel Tent.
Come along and enjoy the fun for mum, dad, boys and girls, there is something for everyone in the family.

item.title: Clifton Hill Primary School Fair
item.description:
The focus is firmly on a great day out for the whole community at Clifton Hill Primary School's annual fundraising Fair.
With carnival games, rides and live entertainment including local covers band Bin Night Romeos, face painting, photo booth, a wine raffle and a huge silent auction (get the Christmas shopping done in one afternoon) it's the most fun you can have at school.
It's no surprise the Clifton Hill Primary School Fair is famous for its gourmet food, being located only minutes from the Fitzroy and Collingwood foodie hubs the gourmet grub on offer reflects the quality and choice of food in the local area.
This year, among others, there is Le Grand BBQ, baked potatoes and fresh pies, Asian delights and an Italian feast. For sweet lovers there's Italian hand made gelato, Dutch pancakes, Norwegian waffles, the classic scones with fresh strawberries and cream, plus homemade cakes.
Wash it all down with something from the coffee cart, the Little Creatures bar or maybe the dedicated daiquiri stand! And of course, it wouldn't be a fair without lollies, popcorn and fairy floss.
Pick up a bargain at Trash and Treasure, browse the plants and craft stalls, stock up on preserves and Christmas cakes while the children enjoy the Gymbus, giant super slide, Jurassic adventure jumping castle, chuggy choo choo adventure train inflatable, chair-o-plane, bungee challenge, farm animals and much more!
The Clifton Hill Primary School Fair is organised and run by parent volunteers with the support of local businesses. For the last three years, all funds raised were used to build and resource a dedicated science lab.
Entry is free, with various prices for rides and games. The Fair starts at 10am, rain or shine, and will run until 4pm.

item.title: Carols by Candlelight - Shepparton
item.description:
Celebrating 40 years of Christmas magic! Shepparton's Queens Gardens will once again come alive with the merry sounds and joyful smiles of Christmas during Carols by Candlelight.
Presented by Greater Shepparton City Council, this beloved family tradition, Carols by Candlelight, has a proud history and on the 21st December 2014 they will celebrate their 40th year!
The night promises to be even more spectacular with the return of various local performers and entertainers who will showcase a mix of contemporary and traditional Christmas carols. The evening will conclude around 9.30pm with the GMCU sound and fireworks masterpiece which is sure to delight the whole family!
It is a free community event and everyone is invited to attend this wonderful celebration!
Attendees are encouraged to bring their own rugs, cushions and chairs.
The local Kiwanis Club will operate a barbecue and refreshments stall from 5:30pm and candles and glow products will be available for purchase.
Reserved accessible seating is available by phoning Riverlinks on (03) 5832 9511. Council has also engaged Auslan Interpreters who will assist the deaf community by translating using sign language.
The ONE FM 98.5 live broadcast will commence at 6.00pm and in the event of wet weather, the event will be held in the multi-purpose pavilion at the Shepparton Showgrounds

item.title: Heaven is as Low as Earth
item.description:
Showing at the Cambridge Studio Gallery, Heaven is as Low as EarthAn exhibition of lyrical abstracts by Magdallene Ektoras.
Borrowed from the ancient Chinese philosopher Hui Shi, Heaven is as Low as Earth underpins this exhibition's theme which seeks to explore the obscure interplay of that which is seen but not quite understood and just out of reach.
Magdallene Ektoras is an abstract artist who is one of only two foreign artists recognised in 2004 for their contribution to abstract art in Shanghai where she resided for over a decade. Mr Li Lei Deputy Director, China Art Museum, Shanghai held a joint exhibition with Magdallene Ektoras and has written glowingly of her talent and abilities. Please see letter below.
Magdallene has received particular acclaim for her monotypes constructed with acrylic on rice paper. The uncommon fusion of the weighty, almost weather-proof surface of acrylic, against the fragile organic nature of rice paper lends to the creation of unique images and textures. She also works with a range of other media, including fabrics and photography.
Heaven is as Low as Earth is Magdallene's first in Melbourne since relocating from Asia. It forms part of a larger body of work which draws inspiration from ancient philosophies and overlooked ideas, in the elusive search to bring meaning to our transient existence.

image.altText: Wandering Beyond, acrylic on rice paper

item.title: Groove Dance Classes at Fed Square
item.description:
Shake up your work day with the new fitness classes just added to Fed Square's Health and Exercise program.
The program runs throughout the year with free classes offered in the morning, lunchtime and evening at various locations around Fed Square.
The program is being expanded to include popular new exercise forms such as zumba and old favourites salsa and swing dancing, alongside freestyle dancing and African drumming to encourage movement and health in an accessible format that anyone can try.
Groove Dance: a simple, fun and interactive dance class where you can forget complex choreography and just groove with Mizz Fitness! Groove Dance.

item.title: Mia Mia Cricket Clubs First Home Match and Family Day
item.description:
Pack the picnic rug, the cucumber sandwiches and your straw hat - Mia Mia Cricket Club is having their first home match and family day.
Let's start the cricket season off with a bang and support their favourite cricketers at their first home game of the season. Bring the friends and family for a great afternoon out - there is heaps of shade and a playground for the young at heart.
Meet them down at the Mia Mia Cricket Ground at 1pm - they will be sizzling sausages to raise money for the club. That's right guys, more fun for more funds!

ns0:venue.name: Mia Mia Recreation Reserve aka "The Flat"

item.ns0:organiser: Ellie McKenna, Marita Rose, Seamus McKenna

item.title: Community Shred Day
item.description:
A Community Shred Day provides the opportunity for the community to bring their confidential documents for shredding while raising money for a good cause. Avoid the risk of identity theft. Don't just throw your confidential documents in the rubbish have them shredded by the state-of-the-art shredding truck. No need to remove clips, plastic sleeves or even folders, - it shreds the lot on-site.
The Community Shred Day will take place from 9am to 2pm at the Elwood Primary School (as part of their school market).
Gold coin donation. There is a limit of five boxes per person. All proceeds will go to Elwood Primary School. Contact operator for more information.

item.title: Hughesdale Primary School 90th Anniversary Reunion Day
item.description: Hughesdale Primary School opened in 1924 as Oakleigh South Primary School. We are celebrating our 90th Anniversary this year with a Reunion Day at the school. Come along and meet up with old friends and teachers. We've got school tours, a huge memorabilia and photo display, an art show, old fashioned games, entertainment from current students and of course food and drink for sale (including devonshire tea, bbq, sandwiches, coffee and frozen yoghurt). Souvenirs on sale including a 90th Anniversary souvenir magazine, KeepCups, Glassware and Teatowels. Pre orders are available through the school for these (not the cakes though!). There will also be a raffle, with tickets available on the day.

item.title: Skateboard Swap Meet with Tony Hallam
item.description:
As part of the exhibition Grommets, Grinds and Gnarly Dudes, The Gallery @ Bayside Arts and Cultural Centre presents Skatebaord Sawp meet with renowned Skateboarder, Tony Hallam.
Come down to the Brighton Town Hall for a Skateboard Swap Meet. If you are interested in Australian skate history, want to collect or swap vintage and new skateboards and accessories, or simply want to reconnect with a part of the skateboard community, this is the event for you.

ns0:venue.name: The Gallery @ Bayside Arts and Cultural Centre

image.altText: Skateboard Swap Meet with Tony Hallam
Skateboard Swap Meet with Tony Hallam

item.title: Baskerville and Richardson: the collection and its care
item.description:
The Gallery at Bayside Arts & Cultural Centre proudly presents Baskerville and Richardson: the collection and its care.
This exhibition presents one of the most significant collections within the Bayside City Council's collection, the works of Margaret Baskerville and C. Douglas Richardson.
Baskerville and Richardson lived in Brighton for many years, working from their home studio in Church Street. Both were renowned 19th century and early 20th century artists working across painting and sculpture.
In addition to showcasing the breadth of the artist's works, this exhibition also provides locals with the opportunity to view two recently conserved works, the popular sculpture The Cloud and the oil painting A Cornish rock.

ns0:venue.name: The Gallery at Bayside Arts and Cultural Centre

image.altText: Baskerville and Richardson: the collection and its care
Baskerville and Richardson: the collection and its care

item.title: Grommets, grinds and gnarly dudes
item.description:
The Gallery at Bayside Arts & Cultural Centre proudly presents Grommets, grinds and gnarly dudes.
In this exhibition, contemporary artists Phillip George, Gerry Wedd and Jud Wimhurst have used various media to highlight aspects of the history and development of (and connection between) surfing and skating.
Each artist has drawn on the rich narratives and visual imagery inherent within these realms to produce contemporary work that critically interrogates our relationship to these sports, and questions the notion of a singular national identity.
Alongside in Gallery One will be the skateboard and ephemera collection from former state champion skate boarder turned skate park designer, Tony Hallam.

ns0:venue.name: The Gallery @ Bayside Arts and Cultural Centre

item.title: Ding Dong Lounge presents
item.description:
Nestled in the heart of Chinatown, Ding Dong Lounge, one of Melbourne's most iconic alternative music venues, present a stellar line-up for Live Music Safari.
A strong east coast trifecta, the event features Sydney folk/soul artist Ngaiire, Melbourne's very own Jakubi and a special guest opener from Brisbane.
Sydney singer/songwriter Ngaiire is building a name for herself as one of the country's most dynamic vocalists and performers. Captivating audiences with her soulful voice and powerful music, Ngaiire is changing the face of Australian folk/soul music. With an Australian Music Prize nomination, a spot at Soulfest, a string of UK shows and a Glastonbury performance under her belt, 2014 is shaping up to be a big year for the artist.
After releasing their first three singles online, in little over four months Melbourne's Jakubi reached one million plays via YouTube and SoundCloud. After this astounding achievement, the hip-hop/pop collective have sold out venues across Australia (including at Ding Dong Lounge) and are set to work on a collaboration with Mike Posner, who is responsible for writing songs for Justin Bieber, Pharrell Williams, Nelly and Snoop Dogg, in the States.

item.title: The Mercat presents
item.description:
A brood of local beat makers and DJs create a bounty of electronic, sonic wonderment deep in the sweaty dance haven that is The Mercat basement.
Recently named one of Melbourne's 'best kept secrets' by Tone Deaf, four piece Rat & Co open hearts with alluring beats born from wide-eyed looks at hard and industrial city environments. On the back of the release of their second album Binary and second single 'Samurai', an ode to Japanese hip-hop producer Nujabes, Rat & Co play live with exceptional company.
Expect enigmatic sets from the crew behind Animals Dancing with resident DJs Otologic, Tornado Wallace and Andee Frost taking turns. Cult figures of Melbourne's underground, well-versed in throwing parties in the depths of The Mercat basement, this collective drop everything from acid house to disco and mash a multitude of trans-atlantic sounds.
Get lost in the haze of smoke machines and take home a limited edition 7 inch, pressed especially, featuring tracks from the night's acts.

item.title: The John Curtin Hotel presents
item.description:
The John Curtin Hotel presents a night of disco discovery through the windows of time.
Opening in shimmering spectacle, the Sugar Fed Leopards are three female singers, accompanied by spangling guitars and a solid rhythm section, who are sure to conjure Ike-and-Tina magic with their soul-twisted disco originals.
Next up is a nine-piece explosion of yacht-rock, RnB and synth-funk. Cult favourites Sex On Toast break out vocal harmonies, talk-box synthesizers, drum machines and choreographed dance moves.
Finally, Vaudeville Smash catapult the night into disco bliss by sweeping crowds into a 1980s montage that inspires conga lines for roller limbo and the application of copious amounts of glitter.

item.title: St Mark's Community Fete
item.description:
Everybody is welcome and invited to St Mark's Community Fete, an annual event which is fun for all ages.
Fun on the day includes, giant raffle, to be drawn at 7pm, exciting rides for everyone from 2pm to 7pm including Jumping castle, Chairoplane, Cup and Saucer, Cha cha, Dodgems, Hurricane, Giant slide, Scouts rope course, Dunking Machine, Choc Toss and Lolly Hunt.
Other fun activities include silent auction and spinning wheel, with many fantastic hampers to be won.
There will be amazing local and international cuisine dining with a licensed bar from 1pm to 7.30pm and live entertainment on stage, Hair twisting, Tattoos, Show bags, Lucky Dips and much, much more.

item.title: The Public Bar presents
item.description:
Back for more in 2014, The Public Bar, North Melbourne's finest dive bar, throws its doors open for another aural expedition of Melbourne acts for Live Music Safari.
Gold Nights, produced by Alex Akers of Forces and released on It Records, has been recognised internationally. White Hex is all 1980s synth, surf guitar and doom vocals set against the cold backlash of a drum machine. The stellar line-up also features local trio Pearls with their sweet melodies, wandering fuzzy guitar lines and hypnotic drums.
Fellow It (Records) kids Little Desert make music with a 1980s post-punk sensibility. Their duelling female vocals and guitar deliver the night's melancholic finale.
Live recordings of the night's performances will be made available free for download.

item.title: 20,000 Days on Earth
item.description:
Before they officially open for the season, Melbourne's favourite summertime cinema warm up the surround sound system with a three-day series of music films especially programmed for MMW.
20,000 Days on Earth which premiered at Sundance to much acclaim. A documentary-not-documentary about the life and times of Australia's dark poet laureate, Nick Cave, it integrates archive and concert footage with re-enactment and staged scenes that may not represent the truth, as it exactly happened, but does represent the truth as it's lived and remembered.
Set over a single day, and directed by visual artists Iain Forsyth and Jane Pollard, it is a smouldering, evocative dive into Cave's myth and his thoughtful, self-aware reflections on the creative process. It is not surprising that Cave has chosen such an innovative way to explore his legacy considering his history with and in some amazing films - from playing a deranged prisoner in Ghosts of the Civil Dead to writing The Proposition, both directed by John Hillcoat.
Track 24 hours with Cave, and a few with Kylie Minogue, that didn't necessarily happen but, nonetheless, elevate the music documentary into warped biopic territory. Then go home and put The Birthday Party on the stereo.

item.title: The Kelvin Club Presents
item.description:
The organisers behind St. Jerome's Laneway Festival deliver their first official Melbourne Music Week event at The Kelvin Club.
This showcase features some of Melbourne's top emerging artists including Japanese Wallpaper, LUCIANBLOMKAMP and Klo.
Staying true to Laneway's objective of hosting forward-thinking artists in unique locations, the historic inner-city venue The Kelvin Club makes for the perfect match.

item.title: The Toff in Town Presents
item.description:
Big local sounds - bellowing vocals and gaining pop by frantic bleeps and turns - take over The Toff in Town for Live Music Safari.
Electronic RnB/soul group The Harpoons are renowned for packing dancefloors, while hyperactive beat-makers Parking Lot Experiments elevate with a whirlwind of hedonistic fun and mayhem.

item.title: Cherry Bar Presents
item.description:
Melbourne's iconic Cherry Bar is religiously rock and roll, but their Soul Thursdays remain one of Melbourne's longest running soul/funk residencies. For Live Music Safari, Cherry Bar shines the spotlight on three emerging local acts from the vibrant soul scene - The Harlots, Stella Angelico and Kingston Crown.
Bluesy rock outfit and triple j Unearthed actThe Harlots have been playing sell-out shows since launching their acclaimed double EP, Coarse Tunes - Parts 1 and 2, and following this year's release, 'Somewhere To Go'.
Stella Angelico have described their style as akin to a soul/rock-meets-disco/Bond soundtrack. Expect big vocals and some serious bass swing to get the dancefloor pumping.
Kingston Crown, a band born from of a shared love of soul and RnB and another triple j Unearthed success story, finish the night's fiery line-up.

item.title: Bennetts Lane Jazz Club presents
item.description:
Bennetts Lane Jazz Club present two rooms of exhilarating live jazz for Live Music Safari.
Swing is the Thing, featuring music from Kelsey James and The Furbelows and dance by Studio 1929, celebrates rollicking 1920s and 30s swing, jive and Lindy Hop. Enter this room and be immersed in the heyday of toe-tapping jazz via the Mills Brothers, Andrews Sisters and Boswell Sisters.
On their resident stage, the Bennetts Lane Big Band astound with the vitality of their contemporary, original big band sounds. Drawing from the very best and innovative talent in Melbourne today, the band features Joseph O'Connor, James Macaulay, Tom Noonan, Kieran Hensey, Jason McMahon, Jon Hunt, Ben Harrison, Callum G'Froerer, Nick Pietsch, Matt McGeachin, Marty Holoubek and James McLean.
Delight in this wonderful spectacle of jazz music and dance, and spend an evening discovering this exuberant and revolutionary art form.

item.title: Live Music Safari launch: Kingswood
item.description:
Indie rock band Kingswood launch this year's Live Music Safari with a special performance at the flagship venue of Melbourne Music Week, Queen Victoria Market.
Kingswood's debut album, produced by Vance Powell (Jack White, Arctic Monkeys and Kings of Leon) in Nashville USA, was released earlier this year and stormed straight to number 6 on the ARIA charts.
Kingswood members are also avid motorbike lovers. In this spirit, Harley-Davidson Street 500 have built The Shed, a temporary motorbike inspired hangout and celebration of creative culture, at Queen Victoria Market for Melbourne Music Week.
Fans can get their hands on the limited number of tickets available for this exclusive opening party through various competitions and promotions in the weeks leading up to the event.

item.title: FasterLouder Lunchbox Series
item.description:
Let music break the daily grind with a full bill of free lunchtime gigs as part of this year's FasterLouder Lunchbox Series at the new flagship venue of MMW, QVM. Since 2010, this popular series has been enlivening the city and providing a welcome interruption to work days. At Lunchbox gigs, enjoy some of the tastiest produce QVM has to offer while a stable of Australian talent take to the stage.
Sui et Sui - Monday 17 November, 12.30pm Sui Zhen, the alias of Becky Sui Zhen, performs her own version of Japanese post punk through a dreamy Balearic-bossa nova filter with her live band Sui et Sui.
Amaya Laucirica - Tuesday 18 November, 12.30pm Laucirica captivates with her beautiful folk melodies and heavenly vocals at one of her final performances before she relocates to Berlin in 2015.
Gold Class - Wednesday 19 November, 12.30pm See Melbourne rock outfit Gold Class bring their fresh savagery and contemporary working-class politics to bright rhythms that hark back to the post punk eras of 1980s Australia and England.
Holy Lotus - Thursday 20 November, 12.30pm Spend lunchtime with Holy Lotus as they perform the kind of joyful, sunny synth pop that suggests they have the power to put winter on hold.
Peter Bibby - Friday 21 November, 12.30pm Make a Friday lunch date with larrikin Peter Bibby whose cigarette-laced vocals and folk/bluesy guitar are deeply embedded in the Australian idiom.

item.title: The Telepathy Project + Sophia Brous
item.description:
Delve into the unconscious spaces of Melbourne's shared gardens, architecture and imagination with this mind-wandering sonic experience.
As part of MPavilion's One Night Stand series of interventions, The Telepathy Project (Veronica Kent and Sean Peoples) invite special guests including hypnotic chanteuse Sophia Brous, following on from her participation in The Barbican Centre's In Dreams: David Lynch Revisited, to come together and celebrate all things celestial for this series of nocturnal and dawn adventures
The resultant recordings of the night's adventures will become a free, sonic experience throughout the week in MPavilion.
This project has been funded as part of the VCA and MCM New Initiatives program, supported by the State Government through Arts Victoria.

item.title: Section 8 and Ferdydurke present
item.description:
Section 8 and Ferdydurke are building a solid reputation for luring crowds with a new era of laneway parties. The two venues pool their highly-tuned party sensibilities to present ZOO, a sensory overload and audio-visual extravaganza for Live Music Safari in Tattersalls Lane.
The iconic laneway closes for a barrage of performance - banging drums, clashing guitars and masterful beats; performance art; improvised approaches to staging and lighting; and a giant, four-storey-high projection wall.
The Zoo line-up includes Brawther, City Calm Down and Paces.

item.title: The Hi-Fi presents
item.description:
The Hi-Fi is proud to present A Basement Show, a nod to the up-and-comers - Magic America, The Good Morrows, Bad Family, Where's Joss and more.
Magic America are the psych rock quartet generating hype and following after the recent release of their single 'I thought I told you'. In the words of Tone Deaf, 'Magic America blend Brit-pop hooks with psyched out rock n roll vibes; they are the local band for fans of The Dandy Warhols, Oasis, and Primal Scream.'
Get set for a wild live set from the Melbourne power-pop-rock outfit The Good Morrows who are duly enjoying praise on the back of their recent single 'Running Around'.
Melbourne's Bad Family are back at The Hi Fi after a phenomenal last minute show in 2013 and Where's Joss, who have spent the year gigging and supporting large shows, complete the stellar line-up.
Toast some of Melbourne's great emerging bands at this energetic Live Music Safari event.

item.title: The Liberty Social presents
item.description:
Requiem present an evening of gothic subcultures at Melbourne dive bar, The Liberty Social.
The city's own bat cave will see Adelaide's Rule of Thirds play songs from their highly-anticipated, long-play debut - a soundtrack to our sparse and mysterious red country. This sextet's wailing female vocals over lashings of guitar, reverberant synth and militant bass and drums is a fresh take on 1970s and 80s Australian gothic rock.
Supports include local purveyors of wave in Repairs, Lakes with their pummelling tribal-rhythms and young upstarts Habits, while trad-goth DJs and members of NUN program sound all evening.
Throughout the night contemporary dance performance artist Agent Cleave leads a troupe of gothicka.
Be swept up in death rock, industrial, gothic and dark wave.

item.title: Honouring Our Heroes: Euroa & District
item.description:
Honouring Our Heroes is a project that involves installing life size bronze statues in honour of the three citizens who were awarded the VC, Lieutenant (later Major) Frederick Harold Tubb, Corporal Alexander Stewart Burton and Lieutenant Colonel Leslie Cecil Maygar.
The project also includes the Memorial Avenue of Honour in Clifton Street, by correcting details and installing the remaining plaques of Euroa's 104 returned servicemen. This has been achieved through grants, donations and voluntary labour.
Construction of VC Memorial Park, adjacent to the RSL in Kirkland Avenue, Euroa is well advanced and proceeding on schedule. Major funding was received from Regional Development Victoria, the TPI Association, Strathbogie Shire Council, the Burton family and Anzac Centenary Commission, and donations came from near and far.
The bronze statues of Alex Burton, Fred Tubb and Leslie Maygar will be placed on black granite plinths immediately before the Opening and Dedication ceremony and unveiled by The Honourable Alex Chernov, AC QC, Governor of Victoria on November 16, 2014.
Members of the public are invited to attend the ceremony at 10.30 am for 11.00 am. A sausage sizzle will be provided afterwards.

item.title: 1000 £ Bend Presents
item.description:
Roll on in to Live Music Safari as Foreign Brothers transform 1000 £ Bend into a roller disco of cosmic proportions and Northside Records present a full line-up of their signature sounds, from hip-hop to soul and reggae through to funk.
Mondo Freaks, the 1980s funk/post-disco crew, bring their layers of synth and extended breaks to the rink and Triple R presenter Chris Gill plugs local winners to keep people rolling with steeze.
PBS's DJ Manchild plays his colourful mix of Bollywood funk, fiery Columbian-salsa and hip-hop and stepping up the calypso, fellow locals Ms Butt and Lewis Cancut serve up their blend of world beats, percussive house and tropical disco.
Holding the philosophy of past Foreign Brothers events, The Roller Jam is intended to bring together people of diverse backgrounds under the banner of peace, love, unity and fun.
Skates are available for hire; fluoro lycra, sweat band sets and glitter are optional. Get ready to roll.

item.title: Soul Safari + The Perfections + Mayfield
item.description:
Embark on an intimate and rousing, genre-spanning journey as Melbourne's best soul bands warm the city for this special edition of Fed Square Live, the weekly summer music series hosted by Fed Square.
Melbourne's Soul Safari have been making waves across Australia. These groove-based music makers wow crowds with their passionate and energetic performances and leave audiences begging for an encore. Blending neo soul, funk, RnB and hip-hop, this is a band with a story to tell.
Next up are The Perfections and their mix of dirty and sweet garage soul. Describing themselves as 'the lovechild of Otis Redding and The Stooges', lead singer Christina sets the stage alight with her commanding vocals and glitter-tastic antics.
The trio of soulful performances rounds out with Mayfield, a vibrant and solid five piece funk/soul crew, playing deep, rich originals. With a raw and honest sound that manages to be fun and electrifying at the same time, Mayfield are guaranteed to get punters up and dancing.

item.title: Lounge Presents
item.description:
Lounge, one of Melbourne's much-loved music venues, joins the dots between emerging and established artists to showcase our city's highly-revered electronic music labels on two stages and with a laneway party for Live Music Safari.
Sleep D comprises Corey Kikos and Maryos Syawish. Part of the delectable Butter Sessions fleet, this artistic duo have spent the best part of their youth exploring sonic soundscapes and ways to share them with other people.
Harvey Sutherland creates warm floating textures of bass and noodling keys with nods to early techno and the 909 drum machine. He is joined by PhD student Tom Day, who first started making music as a means to escape. Day creates lush, cinematic, piano-based pieces layered with electronic hooks.
Cale Sexton, a hardcore punk kid from way back, is up next. Sexton's switch to electronic music happened recently, but in just a short time he has managed to turn heads and hearts on dancefloors.
Fellow champions of the techno scene, Jake Blood, Kangaroo Skull, Voitek and PWD join the fold and M5K brings the beats for this hometown throwdown.

item.title: Live Music Safari Kitchens
item.description:
For Live Music Safari, fourteen of Melbourne's much-loved and iconic live music venues open their doors for a wild night of free gigs and parties, and, for the first time, some are offering food as well.
Try the black angus, kangaroo or saganaki burgers or a spicy quesadilla at 1000 £ Bend. Full menu
Snack on Boney's jalapeno donuts, chicken kofta or cashew and carrot bao buns or fill a bigger appetite with the beef brisket. Full menu
Gloria Swanston's Kitchen at Lounge makes mouth-watering American classics like philly-cheese steaks, Texan BBQ ribs and southern fried green tomato sliders. Full menu
Treat yourself to Thai flavours - perhaps a betel leaf salad with salmon or mushroom dumpling green curry - courtesy of Choo Choo's at The Toff in Town. Full menu
Girl with the Gris Gris serve home-style, Louisiana cooking with a Creole and Cajun menu at Ding Dong. MMW ticket holders can take advantage of their special Live Music Safari offer - an Abita beer and chicken and sausage gumbo for $15. Full menu
Ferdydurke top star-studded frankfurters like the Fred Savage (frank with tequila infused chunky salsa, jalapenos, cheese and sour cream) and nachos too. Full menu
Huxtaburger now have a pop-up kitchen at The John Curtin Hotel. From the Denise to the Sondra, select any one of their much-loved burgers. Full menu
The Kelvin Club plates up carbonara croquets, burgers and an extensive list of cheesy toasties. Full menu
Fancy Hank's BBQ Joint serves traditional American-style, slow-cooked BBQ at The Mercat. Full menu
Miss Katies Crab Shack at The Public Bar boasts a low country boil, fried chicken, burgers and more made using produce from QVM. Full menu

item.title: Boney presents
item.description:
Boney have assembled a slew of Melbourne's chief electronic acts for a Live Music Safari party that spans over two levels, spills into Magic Mountain next door and flows out to a laneway party in Westwood Place.
Upstairs at Boney, Nic Hamilton and This Thing artists Dylan Michél, Kane Ikin and Coup D'etat examine the synchronicity between the contemporary creation of music and video as sounds and visuals are manufactured, found, re-filmed, blurred, slowed-down, sped-up, spliced and reconstructed.
Microwave synth star Versaj (aka Kirkis) plays heartfelt boogie jams to Silentjay and Julien Love serenades with Latin tracks in the downstairs area.
At Magic Mountain, disco darlings Misty Nights facilitate the quest to euphoric, psychedelic disco mayhem. Fashioned by the dream team Danny Hotep and Simon Barrel, Misty Nights steer the most discerning dancefloor in Melbourne.
In the laneway, Edd Fisher and Simon TK of Wax'o Paradiso play with guest Jimmy Caution and support comes from dance crew The Fandroids. Sample the fruits of the concrete jungle as these artists conjure the depths of the Amazon with their impeccable taste in tropical rhythms for Live Music Safari.

item.title: MMusic: Skycha
item.description:
Curated by MPavilion, a new temporary architecture commission and design space based in the Queen Victoria Memorial Gardens, MMusic is a series of free Sunday afternoon listening parties.
Presented by Melbourne Recital Centre, Melbourne-based vocalist and composer Chantal Mitvalsky headlines the first MMusic.
For the past 10 years, Mitvalsky has been making waves in the jazz world as a solo artist, recording artist and backing vocalist. Her latest project, under the pseudonym Skycha, sees her pushing boundaries and blending acoustic and electronic sounds. Skycha is raw and soulful with elements of soul, contemporary hip-hop and traditional jazz.
Joining Mitvalsky in this intimate performance are some of Melbourne's musical elite, including Kumar Shome on guitar, Hugh Harvey on drums and special guest pianist Sam Keevers.

item.title: What's up Downunder Concert & Fireworks
item.description:
The What's up Downunder Concert for charity features Eurogliders, Wendy Stapleton Trio, Angie Hilton and special guests.
The evening will finish with a fireworks display, which is weather permitting.
Price: Free entry Time: 5pm
Bring your own chairs, with food & drinks available on site, so come along and enjoy a night of fun and entertainment.

item.title: African Drumming, Thilaka Kulathunga & Dudi Shaul
item.description:
Through cultural programs held in Australia, India and Nepal, the Music Generation (MGen) aims to connect people from various cultures through music. MGen are partnering with MMW to present Thilaka Kulathunga, Dudi Shaul and African Drumming's Sessi Sessi group. While they play a diverse range of music from around the world, they still call Melbourne home.
Thilaka Kulathunga's career dates back to the 1970s when she started playing sitar professionally in Sri Lanka; she has now performed across three continents. As a prominent teacher of this beautiful instrument, she believes that music allows feelings to be expressed as a universal language and that it is healing for the soul. Aman Kalyan accompanies Kulathunga on the tabla.
Dudi Shaul is a Melbourne-based guitarist who is undertaking an explorative journey into the world of nylon string guitars. Fuelled by his passion for folk and ethnic musical cultures, combined with the finesse of his classical training and the raw energy of Afro-Brazilian rhythms, Dudi shares a distinctive and diverse musical experience with his audience.
A special surprise is scheduled for the close of the show courtesy of Melbourne's own African Drumming group, Sessi Sessi. African Drumming are dedicated to sharing the powerful music and culture of West Africa to a wider audience through classes, workshops, study tours and performances.

item.title: Morning Ritual
item.description:
A call for music lovers to rise and shine, Morning Ritual's free morning gigs are back to plant big smiles on faces, first-thing.
Now an Melbourne Music Week breakfast staple, Morning Ritual offers a superior start to the day. Expect a mixture of genres to complement the early(ish) rise. This year's all-local line-up is as feel good as bircher and has the heart of a BLT, all happily perked-up with two shots of espresso.
The birds have been beating people to it since the dawn of time; this is a chance to get ahead and catch the worm (metaphorically, not digestively). The line-up is well-worth the morning effort.

item.title: Violet Town Preschool Art Exhibition - Children's Week 2014
item.description:
Violet Town Kindergarten in partnership with Strathbogie Shire are putting on a children's art exhibition as part of celebrations for Children's Week 2014 across the shire.
Children attending the kinder will produce a number of artworks for the exhibition which will be open to the public, immediate and extended family members will be invited to attend and it will be promoted to the wider community.
The exhibition opens at 5.30pm on Monday 20th October 2014.

item.title: Saturday Morning Activity Session
item.description:
Come along to this special Children's Week Activity Session and listen to stories, play games, win prizes, and paint a plate to take home with you.
Bookings are required for this free event. Please phone operator to secure your place.
Saturday, 25 October 2014 from 10.00am to 11.30am at Bairnsdale Library.

item.title: Reading Development: Stages not Ages Literacy Talk
item.description:
Reading Development: Stages not Ages Literacy Talk offers information for parents presented by Jennifer Graham - Literacy Specialist.
Jennifer Graham has been a school teacher for fifteen years in a number of settings, and as a literacy specialist helping children with reading and writing delays.
Stages not ages is a talk for parents and carers, and covers the following stages of reading development: books as food, books as toys, recognising that books have pictures, realising that books tell a story, beginning to recognise letters, beginning to recognise words and comprehension.
Bookings required. Phone operator to book. Event starts at 5.00pm.

item.title: The Flying Bookworm Theatre - Children's Week 2014 in Avenel
item.description:
Avenel Preschool in partnership with Strathbogie Shire are bringing to life some of their most favourite stories to life with The Flying Bookworm theatre performance as part of celebrations for Children's Week 2014 across the shire.
The Flying Bookworm Theatre Company will perform a live version of three books for the children and their families from Avenel Pre-school and Avenel Primary School. Additionally, invitations have been extended to Longwood Primary School and children and families of the wider community.

item.title: Garden of Forking Paths
item.description:
Ever wanted to touch the artwork? Now you can. Play an original 1980s computer game, the world's first ever art game, on a historic Commodore 64 machine!
Get your hands on a CD-rom! See what the internet used to look like when it first began. Talk to a robot on a vintage TV! See how iPads are your own personal mini art gallery. Play with the latest in technology: the cutting edge Oculus Rift headwear!
dLux MediaArts presents Garden of Forking Paths, a daring exhibition curated by Neil Jenkins which draws together notable historic and contemporary examples of computer games that push the bounds of the genre and break the orthodox set of rules and redefine what a game, or an artwork, can be.

item.title: What is a B Corporation and how do you become one?
item.description:
Please join Brad Dunn, Founder of Certified B Corp Nazori, and Alicia Darvall, Executive Director of B Lab Australia, for an informative morning tea to find out more about how to become a B Corp and their plans for B Corporations in Australia.
What is a B Corp? B Corps are a global movement of business leaders that seek to redefine success in business, so that one day all companies compete not only to be the best in the world, but to be the best for the world. The aim is that, in a generation's time, all businesses will measure and manage their impact as readily as they do profitability.
To become a B Corp, businesses are certified by the non-profit B Lab to meet rigorous standards of social and environmental performance, accountability, and transparency.
This event is presented by B Lab.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Visualising Health
item.description:
Visualising Health is a digital media exhibition that showcases the diverse visual knowledge exchange activities within the Faculty of Medicine, Dentistry and Health Sciences at the University of Melbourne and the broader Parkville health precinct.
This innovative exhibition will be displayed within a pop-up space on the University campus and will promote knowledge transfer and greater public engagement around the core theme of 'health and wellbeing'. See examples of cutting-edge biomedical research and novel ways of communicating health information on a large digital wall.
This event is presented by the Gateway Health Sciences Project.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

ns0:venue.name: University of Melbourne, Alan Gilbert Building

item.title: Visual Arts in Health Education Demonstration Session
item.description:
At first glance a crisp white doctor's coat may look slightly out of place in the quiet calm of an art gallery, but an innovative partnership program at the University of Melbourne is drawing a new picture of teaching and learning.
Dr Heather Gaunt, the Potter's Curator of Academic Programs (Research), will lead this masterclass where participants will discover how studying art increases visual observation skills that can then be applied to clinical scenarios. You will be taken through the program that is run for medical and dentistry students.
This event is presented by the Ian Potter Museum of Art, University of Melbourne.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

ns0:venue.name: The Ian Potter Museum of Art, University of Melbourne

image.altText: Visual Arts in Health Education Demonstration Session
Visual Arts in Health Education Demonstration Session

item.title: Visual Arts in Health Education
item.description:
Led by Dr Heather Gaunt, the Potter's Curator of Academic Programs (Research), a team of academics and professionals from the University of Melbourne has been exploring ways to incorporate visual observation, reflection and interpretation into the learning process for medical, dentistry, vet and science students. The panel will discuss the range of innovative engagements that the Potter is making with students across health and veterinary science.
Panel members include:
- Associate Professor Mina Borromeo, Convenor, Special Needs (Dentistry)
- Associate Professor Clare Delany, Director of Teaching and Learning at the School of Health Sciences, The University of Melbourne and Senior Ethics Associate at the Children's Bioethics Centre at the Royal Children's Hospital
- Dr Cathy Beck, Senior Lecturer in Diagnostic Imaging, Veterinary Science.
This event is presented by The Ian Potter Museum of Art, University of Melbourne.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

ns0:venue.name: The Ian Potter Museum of Art

item.title: Vider Paris
item.description:
Vider Paris, an early work by renowned French artist Nicolas Moulin, is a software-based installation that presents a series of still images of Paris, accompanied by a haunting soundtrack.
This exhibition forms part of Topographic Landscapes, a series of exhibitions of turn-of-the-century screen-based works that incorporate computer-graphics to generate landscapes, curated by Simone Hine and Kyle Weise.

item.title: Vic International Research Scholarships Knowledge Exchange
item.description:
Chaired by Victoria 's Lead Scientist Leonie Walsh, this event brings four brilliant international research scholars from three countries (China, Singapore, India) together to share their doctoral research and its future impact on our city.
These young researchers will take you on a journey to discover how humans are continuing the fight against influenza, and how a matrix of mini solar cells can be used in a form of paint to generate green energy. We will also explore how information on our everyday travel patterns can improve urban planning, as well as how we can improve our treatment of cancer using the power of biomarkers.
This event showcases the research of four recipients of the Victorian International Research Scholarship, brilliant young researchers attracted from around the world to complete their research in Victoria.
This event is presented by Study Melbourne, Department of State Development, Business and Innovation.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

ns0:venue.name: Dept of State Development, Business and Innovation

item.title: Undercoat Seasonal Collection: 2014 Launch
item.description:
Undercoat is a community dedicated to collecting and sharing the most beautiful, inspiring and innovative content from creative students and established professionals.
In 2014, they have curated works that represent the Melbourne seasons illustrating the local creative life and Melbourne's overall creative influence globally.
By exploring spring, summer, autumn and winter, they are investigating how artistic endeavours change over the course of the year and are affected by the seasons. Their contributors are from many walks of life, including photographers, writers, illustrators, scientists and filmmakers.
They will also be launching the 2014 collection of Overcoat magazines.
The exhibition features works from: Adam Trovarelli, April Wright, Chris Kastner, Duncan Meerding, Eevien Tan, Hayley Walker, Jamie Richey, Jessica Tremp, Ness Flett, Nipun Srivastava, Salvador Morales, Shelley Horan, Sunny Nyssen and Tinja Berg
The Undercoat Seasonal Collection is supported by the City of Melbourne, as a recipient of their Annual Arts Grants Program.

item.title: Under the Coverslip
item.description:
Under the Coverslip (UTCS) is a student-run art exhibition that showcases scientific images from a range of institutions and disciplines. UTCS originated as a way for students within The University of Melbourne's Department of Anatomy and Neuroscience to exhibit interesting images they had taken during the year and as an informal end of year celebration for the Honours students. Over the years, the exhibition has grown in both size and scope, culminating with UTCS sharing an exhibition space with 'Visualising Health' as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.
The images are intended to not only be eye-catching and aesthetically pleasing but to engage with the public and inform them of the ground-breaking scientific research being conducted within the Parkville Precinct and throughout Victoria.
Under the Coverslip 2014 is presented by the Postgraduate Students of Anatomy Society.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Treasures of North Melbourne's Local History Collection
item.description:
North Melbourne Library is 140 years old and, over that time, there have been an array of precious, rare and odd items collected for the local history collection. Come and see some of these items and how they connect to the area.
This is one of the fun activities taking place across the City of Melbourne's library branches during History Week.

item.title: This Used to be the Future
item.description:
Josh Lord presents his latest exhibition, This Used to be the Future, a confronting and challenging body of work which explores the difference between the vision of the future and the reality, socially, politically, economically and also creatively.
The opening night features live performances by Ash Wednesday and Ollie Olsen.

item.title: The Conscious Closet Women's Clothing pop-up
item.description:
Shop at this women's pop-up shop in the heart of Melbourne's where you will find pre-loved and new designer clothing and accessories at bargain prices.
The not-for-profit organisation Fitted for Work often receives generous donations of clothing that is sometimes not work appropriate, so it is offered for sale at bargain prices in a monthly pop-up boutique. Clothing, accessories, handbags and shoes from brands such as Scanlan and Theodore, Carla Zampatti, Cue, Veronika Maine and Anthea Crawford will be on sale, with prices starting at $2.
All proceeds go towards Fitted for Works' free services and programs that help women in the community step out of disadvantage and into work. Since 2005, more than 14,500 women have been helped to transform their lives by securing sustainable employment.

item.title: The Collaborative School Day
item.description:
Learn to stretch the limits of your imagination, define the future of education and sample the new education phenomena of co-learning at Hub Melbourne.
Join 60 intent learners in the Hub Melbourne Club house and explore the new education phenomena of Co Learning, an idea based on The Student Organized Learning Environment (S.O.L.E) developed by researcher and TEDprize winner Sugata Mitra.
The Collaborative School Day is a collaboration between Hub Melbourne and two of their youngest members Remy Grangien (16 years) and Simon Harman (17 years), who have already set up their first enterprise, 'The Co Learners'. They are passionate about redefining what the education system looks like in Australia, and building a collaborative learning movement that inspires students to invest in their own personal learning development.
The days starts with An Introduction to Collaborative Learning, followed by Office Hours, where a pool of mentors and experts on a range of topics can help you pinpoint exactly what it is that you want to learn. With your learning purpose in mind, you'll be launched into The Knowledge Grid, a huge diversity of workshops on the top trending topics for youth. There'll be knowledge-sharing and a panel discussion on the Future of Learning, so come along for a unique experience of future learning at The Collaborative School Day!
This event is presented by Hub Melbourne.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Systems Biology: Understanding Human Disease
item.description:
