The Human Genome Project of 2001 ushered in a new era of research in which the molecular components of living systems could be identified and enumerated. The challenge now is to understand how these components interact with one another, and use this information to combat disease.
Systems Biology brings together computing and engineering approaches to meet this challenge. Professor Edmund Crampin, Rowden White Chair of Systems and Computational Biology and Director of the Systems Biology Laboratory at the University of Melbourne, will outline how Systems Biology research provides new insights into the mechanisms of disease, and paves the way for new diagnostics and targeted therapies. His research focuses on developing mathematical and computational models to investigate the molecular networks underlying complex human diseases, including heart disease and cancer.
The University of Melbourne is ranked 32nd in the world and first in Australia for Engineering and Technology (Times Higher Education).
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week.

item.title: Superscience in Supercomputers
item.description:
Did you know that the world's largest supercomputer devoted to life science research is driving major research advances right here in Melbourne?
Get a glimpse of research at the cutting edge as four leading Victorian scientists explain how their work is adding to our understanding of the world.
Speakers include: - Associate Professor Tiffany Walsh (Institute for Frontier Materials, Deakin University), who is looking for ways to copy nature's building blocks to make new nano-materials - Dr Michael Kearney (Department of Zoology, University of Melbourne), who is modelling how animals might be affected by future climate scenarios - Professor Melissa Southey (Department of Pathology, University of Melbourne), who is using complex data analysis techniques to characterise what defines an individual's predisposition to common cancers - Dr Torsten Seemann (Victorian Bioinformatics Consortium, Monash University), who uses genomics and bioinformatics to characterise infectious disease outbreaks.
Join the experts afterwards for morning tea and further conversation.
This event is presented by the Victorian Life Sciences Computation Initiative.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

ns0:venue.name: Woodward Conference Centre, University of Melbourne

item.title: Stop Apologising for Your Arts Degree
item.description:
Arts students are often forced to defend their decision to study the humanities. They are told they will never find a job with such a 'useless' degree, that their studies are 'pretentious', and that science, law and finance are more worthy educational pursuits.
In this forum, Karen Hitchcock, Lisa Gorton and chair Hannie Rayson will explain the ways in which their humanities backgrounds have helped them in their careers - careers one would not readily associate with the humanities. They will show how the skills acquired through studying history, literature and philosophy are useful and applicable in a wide range of careers and industries.
Sourcing and identifying relevant information, thinking critically and writing persuasively are just some of those skills and they are ever more relevant in our fast-paced, globalised society. Equally important are the social awareness, ability to empathise and lessons from the past that are instilled in humanities students.
Non-profit advocacy group Humanities 21 aims to help the humanities receive a better hearing from educational funders, based on a greater recognition of their contribution to society. The humanities unlock a special kind of knowledge and create a special kind of thinker, helping people to fulfil their potential and lead flourishing lives. Now, more than ever, the world needs these kinds of people. This forum will demonstrate why dismissing the humanities is both an unwise and costly mistake.
This event is presented by Humanities 21 as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

ns0:venue.name: The Wheeler Centre Books Writing Ideas

item.title: Speakers University Intensive - Public Speaking Workshop
item.description:
Andy Harrington explains how you can create influence, make an impact and make ten times more income.
Right now you are probably sitting on an untapped goldmine!
When you learn to share your uniquely gained knowledge and experience with others in a bigger and better way your life will never be the same again! There is no greater skill to acquire than speaking to, influencing and having impact on large groups of people to promote yourself or your business.
Andy Harrington's Speakers University Intensive is a powerful training workshop where you will learn:
- His proven step-by-step system to put together the perfect presentation - Techniques in action that work in front of thousands of people - Attendees coached LIVE on stage to transform their on stage performance - His Stress Free Speaker System to present confidently without ever running out of something to say. - The structure to build lucrative one-day and multi-day workshops so you get paid even more money - How to build your talk point by point so you'll be the most captivating speaker your company, university or industry has ever seen.
Sign up now to this free workshop and learn the skills you need to get up on stage, without anxiety!

item.title: Sounds of Spring Racing
item.description:
Set in the luxurious Market Lane Bar, the Sounds of Spring Racing series is designed to showcase the best of Melbourne's emerging musicians and artists as well as offering a lavish after-party destination for race-goers and the public on key race days.
The series will kick off with Caulfield Cup on Saturday 18 October, where talented musicians and artists from Melbourne's leading entertainment and creative industries college JMC Academy, will serenade guests into the night with an assortment of indie-pop, acoustic and soul.
Sounds of Spring Racing is a free event open to the public, and will be held from 6pm - 9pm on key race days as listed below.
Artists Schedule: Caulfield Cup, Saturday 18 October: Julz and Erin Cox Plate, Saturday 25 October: Brittany Worthy (Chachi) Derby Day, Saturday 1 November: Duncan, Alex and Shawnee Oaks Day, Thursday 6 November: Julz and Erin Stakes Day, Saturday 8 November: Brittany Worthy (Chachi)

item.title: Sound of Drawing
item.description:
Experienced artists from Polyglot Theatre guide children through creative drawing exercises on a table wired for sound.
With a variety of drawing materials, the artists engage the participants in a series of drawing experiences on a large sheet of paper where the sound of the pastel or crayon is picked up by a sensitive microphone and amplified. The physical action of the drawing is turned into a unique soundscape with the final shared drawing artwork exhibited within the space.
Suitable for children aged 3 to 12 years.
This event is presented by Polyglot Theatre.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Social Media and the Law
item.description:
How has the practice of law been impacted by social media and how are laws adapting to this changing media landscape? Social networks like Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube, blogs and wikis have changed the way information is published and accessed. People exchange more information with more people, more frequently than ever and this has implications for many areas of Australian law.
In this seminar, Professor Patrick Keyzer, Head of La Trobe University's Law School, will discuss issues confronting lawyers and the judiciary, in particular, the implications and consequences of social media use by jurors.
Marc Trabsky will consider the challenges faced by the courts and parliament in developing appropriate legal mechanisms for addressing the authorised disclosure of personal information on social networks.
Professor Keyzer and Mr Trabsky will be joined in this discussion by David Lowden, Senior Lecturer of Journalism at La Trobe University, and Dr Andre Oboler, CEO of the Online Hate Prevention Institute.
This event is presented by La Trobe University.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Social Christmas Day Lunch
item.description:
If you're not participating in the traditional family Christmas this year, come and join the Melbourne Social Club and the Newcomers Network for a Christmas picnic lunch in Queen Victoria Gardens.
Catch up with new friends enjoying Christmas Day in Melbourne at this free event. BYO food, drink, picnic blankets and outdoor games equipment for a leisurely festive picnic on the grass just opposite the National Gallery. Look for the Fun, Food and Friendship banner or Melbourne Social Club or Newcomers Network sign.

item.title: Smart Cities with Digital Skins
item.description:
The internet and 'smart' technology are already impacting the way we understand and use cities. Hear how sensors are changing our lives and how we use and manage metadata. Will 'smart cities' deliver greater economic and public good? What about liveability and privacy? Get the knowledge, join in and have your say.
Panellists include: - MC Antony Funnell, presenter, 'Future Tense', ABC Radio National - Mr William Confalonieri, Chief Digital Officer, Deakin University - Prof Marimuthu (Palani) Palaniswami - Director, Intelligent Sensors, Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, University of Melbourne - Mr Martin Janse van Rensburg, Alliance Manager, Industry Solutions Group Ecosystems, Cisco Systems - Ms Vanessa Toholka, broadcaster with RRR Byte Into IT, Knowledge Management Consultant, Minter Ellison, Melbourne
This event is presented by Melbourne Conversations, City of Melbourne, and Deakin University as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Slide Night: Animating the Inanimate
item.description:
What does the future of augmented reality look like? Arena Theatre Company will present their second Slide Night as part of its ongoing conversation about innovation, technology and the arts. This year, two experts will speak about innovations in animating inanimate objects.
The first speaker will discuss the latest advances in augmented reality and what augmented reality future looks like.
The second speaker is an expert in creative use of robotics who will look at how robots can be employed within a narrative context.
This event is presented by Arena Theatre Company.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Silicon Beach: Melbourne Knowledge Week Special Event
item.description:
Are you interested in founding or working in start-ups, web design and development or mobile technology?
Silicon Beach is Australia's largest tech start-up community, with over 2300 members in Melbourne and nearly 6000 across six capital cities.
Take advantage of this unique opportunity to network with a diverse range of tech entrepreneurs on the cutting-edge of internet innovation. Learn what they do and collaborate with this innovative community of entrepreneurs.
This event is presented by Melbourne Silicon Beach as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Signal Screen Commissions
item.description:
Signal is pleased to present a series of screen-based commissions created by five talented young artists for exhibition on the Signal Screen.
See experimental, abstract and video works by Trent Crawford, Guled Abdulwasi, Claire Kopietz, Celeste Veldze and Nik Lee with support from Michael Meneghetti.
Presented by Signal - City of Melbourne.

item.title: Science and Arts Colliding (DICE Lecture)
item.description:
The DICE - Dialogues on Innovation, Creativity and Entrepreneurship - Lecture intends to explore Australia's complex relationship with risk and risk-takers in the context of an increasingly knowledge-based economy.
The Carlton Connect Initiative's 3rd Annual DICE Lecture will be presented by leading scientist and Boyle medallist, Professor Luke O'Neill of Trinity College, Dublin. Exploring the interactions between art and science through innovative approaches, Professor O'Neill will recount his experience with the wildly successful 'Science Gallery' in Dublin.
This interactive session will consider the potentials of bridging the gap between these often disparate disciplines. Artists, designers and scientists have the opportunity to foster innovation together, and a new medium emerges for the wider community to interact and engage with new ideas.
This event is presented by Carlton Connect Initiative, University of Melbourne.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Sausage and Cider Taste Festival
item.description:
Celebrate the arrival of cider season at The Last Jar's inaugural Sausage and Cider Taste Festival.
The pub and rooftop garden will be transformed into an Irish street fair, showcasing ciders from each of the cider houses, matched with a selection of homemade sausages by the head chef, Tim Sweeney. The perfect condiment to spring sunshine, Sweeney's selection of homemade sausages (served on house-baked potato bread) will be matched with zesty ales and smouldering tunes from Anne of the Wolves for an afternoon of entertainment.
View sausage-making demonstrations from Sausages Made Simple's Sara Grazia or simply enjoy the sausage fest with a sausage and cider in the beer garden.
Presented by The Last Jar in partnership with Mountain Goat, Magners Irish Cider, Harcourt and St Ronan's Ciders.

item.title: RMIT Interactive Technologies Showcase
item.description:
Come and experience innovative interactive technologies developed at RMIT's School of Computer Science and IT. Hear about innovations in big data, mobile technologies and the internet of things. This event showcases a range of projects, including applications in smart transportation, interactive games for training, responding to disasters, social computing, warehouse management and sustainability.
RMIT is a leading university within the City of Melbourne and the School of Computer Science and IT is one of the largest in Australia. The School offers courses and performs research in Interactive Gaming, Visualisation of Sensor Data, Simulation, Localisation, Artificial Intelligence, Web Search, Big Data Analytics, Cloud Computing and Security.
This event is presented by RMIT School of Computer Science and IT.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: RMIT Global Futures Forum
item.description:
Join ABC News Breakfast's Michael Rowland as he hosts a panel discussion with prominent industry figures to identify the challenges and opportunities facing global business.
As part of Melbourne Knowledge Week, the College of Business is bringing together thought leaders from the worlds of finance, technology, energy, social enterprise and the media to explore the theme, 'Designing Sustainable Business Models'.
Held at RMIT University's magnificent Swanston Academic Building and filmed for ABC Big Ideas, it promises to be a lively Q&A style debate that will forge new ways of thinking and new connections as we consider what it means to be innovative, responsible and economically viable in the world of business today.
The support of Amcham and Melbourne Business Network ensures a rich conversation with industry from a local and global perspective.
Industry guests include: - Michael Rowland, news presenter, ABC - The Hon. Lord Mayor Mr Robert Doyle, City of Melbourne - Saul Eslake, Economist & Futurist, Bank of America Merrill Lynch Australia - Christie Cooper, news reporter, Channel 7 - Anoushka Gungadin, CEO, The Duke of Edinburgh's Award Australia, Victoria - Sarah Harland, GM Technology Group Functions, ANZ Bank - Stephen Davy, CEO, Hydro Tasmania - Ross Hill, Director, Business Development APAC, Cotap - Ben Spincer, Director and CTO Technology, Strategy and Innovation, Telstra
This event is presented by RMIT University - College of Business.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

ns0:venue.name: RMIT College of Business, Swanston Academic Building 80

item.title: Re-thinking the Smart City
item.description:
Explore what a smart city is and particularly, how government, residents, and the private sector can work together more effectively to create stronger, more resilient communities.
This will be a roll-up-your-sleeves kind of event that will convene innovators from local governments and mix it up with civic-minded technologists, designers, community organisers, and entrepreneurs.
Guest speakers include Mark Elliot, Founder and Managing Director of Collabforge who will give a snapshot of the power of collaboration, and Steve Bennet, data guru at Code for Australia.
Expect data visualisations, real insight into what is happening behind town hall and a bunch of tools that you can use to make Melbourne a Smart City.
This event is presented by Code for Australia.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Readings from Melbourne Subjective
item.description:
The Cartridge Family is a Melbourne based group of emerging writers.
Be provoked and amused by readings from their recently launched anthology 'Melbourne Subjective' from poet and essayist Kevin Brophy, avant-garde novelist Antoni Jach, poet and performance artist Gayelene Carbis and memoirist Lea Weaver.
Refreshments will be served, this is a free event.

item.title: Pyramids and Labyrinths
item.description:
Pyramids and Labyrinths is Tim Sterling's first solo exhibition in Melbourne since returning from a three-month Australia Council for the Arts studio residency in Paris.
During his stay, he researched barricade construction throughout Paris' various revolutions. These constructions often re-occurred in similar areas using similar techniques despite gaps in time of up to 100 years or more.
Sterling's installation follows this interest of narrative in architecture as both a conceptual and physical space. Re-imagined as a three-dimensional page, various objects are dotted throughout the gallery. Walking through the maze-like space, the objects encountered appear physically unstable, reflecting and distorting their surroundings.

item.title: Performprint: Skater Editions
item.description:
Skateboarding meets printmaking in this dynamic series of live art events exploring the possibilities of print.
Join experimental live art outfit Performprint each Saturday across November to print with large-scale text, carved skateboard wheels, ramps, lawn rollers, gravity, big letters, tonnes of paper and a lot of ink.
Presented by Signal - City of Melbourne.

item.title: Persona-lise
item.description:
Unveil your game persona in Persona-lise, a workshop designed for those interested in gamification and understanding how to personalise its approach.
Any number of things that we do in our daily lives have already been gamified - how we get fit, how we learn, how we talk with others. When it comes to the design of these systems and understanding the users, gamified systems have the potential to be highly effective in not only short-term, but also long-term engagement.
In this workshop, you will begin a journey into an exciting and evolving area of gamified design. You will be able to explore the basic processes used to create enjoyable, engaging and motivating systems, and understand how to implement them. Participants will gain a better understanding about the concept of gamification and how to design more meaningful gamified systems by working in their Persona groups to create a paper prototype of a gamified system.
This event is presented by RMIT University Games and Experimental Entertainment Lab (GEElab).
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Perfect Match
item.description:
Perfect Match looks at the secrets to success for collaborations between research institutions and industry partners. Many businesses consider working with researchers to help their business develop new products and processes, or solve a difficult problem, to stay ahead in a competitive, global marketplace. However, the relationship doesn't always get off the ground. This can be due to uncertainty at how to get started, cultural differences between research institutions and industry and conflicting aims for the relationship.
Perfect Match will look at how Victorian research and industry partners have overcome these barriers to form successful research collaborations in an entertaining and interactive forum. Real life industry and researcher 'couples' will be interviewed on stage about the big questions in their relationship: how did they meet, what attracted them to each other, how did they overcome any differences and what have they achieved together? This free event is open to the public, with particular relevance for start-ups, businesses, researchers and tertiary students with an interest in applied research partnerships.
NICTA is Australia's largest information and communications technology (ICT) research and development centre. It pursues high-impact, original research in partnership with industry and governments that is inspired by real-world challenges. NICTA Victoria is home to ICT researchers and students from around the world specialising in areas of ICT research such as optimisation and data analytics.
This event is presented by NICTA.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

ns0:venue.name: The Wheeler Centre Books Writing Ideas

item.title: Peonies and Dragons
item.description:
The symbiotic relationship between China and Indonesia has existed for centuries. The influence has been ubiquitous. Sometimes, due to the vagaries of the winds, other times by choice or for economic or political reasons, Chinese stayed in the Spice Islands for a while or permanently. Inevitably many of these visitors and migrants married Indonesian people and brought with them their own preferences, tastes and physical and cultural objects.
The Chinese, like others, were interested in the spices the Archipelago produced and paid for these with whatever appealed to the market - 'trade' ceramics, silk, cotton, metal coins, then food (tea, noodles and soya products, for instance) and so on. The exhibition includes a full dance and music program as well as food, literature, entertainment and more.
The workshop program includes:
October 4: Ms Dewi Anggreani, Indonesian writer on Chinese Women in Indonesia. Dewi's latest book on Chinese women will be launched and available during this workshop.
October 11: Ibu Diana, chef and caterer at Nyonya Food.
October 18: Ms Marjorie Ho on trade ceramics.
October 25: Professor Margaret Kartomi on Chinese inspirations in the performing arts of Indonesia, accompanied by a dance.

item.title: Never Real, Always True
item.description:
Having undertaken training with Chinese master painters, French-born artist Christophe Stibio's practice revolves around patience and control.
Christophe Stibio is not afraid of the land. He endeavours to plough it mentally. His art is the visual and tangible result of a profound mental geology of a country which has both physical and spiritual dimensions.
On a formal level, Stibio's multilayered landscapes are utterly sophisticated in their construct. Stibio employs Chinese rice-paper, watercolours and shredded documents as applied materials. The use of shredded documents is a recent addition to his artistic practice. Often confidential, these shreds of paper now form crucial compositional elements to the landscapes. They even play a pivotal role in the narratives of the pictures as they become an integral part of an exploration into the essence of the Australian landscape.

item.title: Nepal Festival 2014
item.description:
Take a journey through the heart of Nepal with the Nepal Festival 2014 at Fed Square!
This all-day event is a recreation of the joyful cultural festivals of Nepal, bringing Fed Square to life with singing, dancing, festivities and lots of food. Be transported to the bustling, ancient city of Kathmandu and explore the traditions of Nepal from east to west and north to south through an array of cultural activities.
Enjoy free entertainment with the official opening of festival, live performances of Nepalese music and dance, a fashion parade and more. Taste authentic Nepalese flavours at the food market along River Terrace and browse an exhibition of Nepalese arts and crafts, photographs and paintings.
Bring your family and friends along and experience the rich cultural landscape of Nepal.

item.title: Navigating the 24-Hour City
item.description:
Inner Melbourne continues to grow and thrive as a popular night time destination. This forum will bring together thinkers in public space and personal navigation technology to explore how to celebrate, develop and contribute to the navigation of people through Melbourne at night.
The forum will: - present the context of the 24-hour city and the role such vitality plays in the knowledge economy - discuss the design of public space to support safety and liveliness - present a prototype mobile web tool that has been developed by RMIT and Road Safety Action Group Inner Melbourne (RSAGIM) that can make it easier for people to navigate their city easily and safely at night. This smartphone application can provide access to quick and accurate information for people visiting Melbourne venues at night. - look at technologies of live data sourcing to provide integrated travel, amenity information and analytics and how they might inform the way we design our future public spaces - involve participants in feedback on navigating the 24 hour city using smart phone technology.
This event is presented by RMIT and Road Safety Action Group Inner Melbourne (RSAGIM).
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: My Kinda Kind
item.description:
My Kinda Kind will be a day of interactive discussion, creative activities, group work and a chance for attendees to take part in honest and open conversation.
The day will also include a 'Think Tank' - A hub to allow attendees to give their opinions and suggestions on what they believe The Kindness Effect should focus on in its future workshops and what areas and issues are most pressing in the world today.
The day will be broken up with special guest speakers, relaxation activities & nutritious food.
If you are passionate about making a change and enjoy honest and open conversations and activities and want to have fun, come along and let yourself be pushed outside of your comfort zone!

item.title: Melbourne Social Club Drinks Night
item.description:
Come along and enjoy a social drinks drinks night at The Fringe, hosted by the Melbourne Social Club.
This free event is open to everyone, with drinks available at bar prices. Come along and meet some of the hosts and club members and start enjoying a great social life in Melbourne.

item.title: Materian – Victorian Advanced Material Showcase
item.description:
Materian is an exciting new design-led project which aims to identify the most innovative and advanced materials being created locally.
The project inspires dialogue between researchers, manufacturers and designers to explore new applications and opportunities for these materials and then to showcase the results both locally and globally with a travelling exhibition and a market awareness campaign.
Victorian researchers are leading the way in fields such as biomimicry, a new science that studies nature's models and then uses these designs and processes to solve human problems.
This event is presented by Design Institute of Australia (DIA) and Design Research Institute of RMIT University as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

ns0:venue.name: Design Gallery, Design Institute of Australia

item.title: Marco Polo Marathon
item.description:
The Marco Polo marathon offers a day of guided cross-cultural activities focusing on language and writing. The event is open to all writers, readers, translators and language enthusiasts. English will be the main communication language - with optional and occasional Mandarin. The marathon is coordinated by the Marco Polo Project, a digital non-profit organisation facilitating the collaborative translation of new writing from China.
Program includes:
- keynote address on the art of translation, reflecting on changes due to the development of the internet
- a morning 'all-you-can-translate' hackathon, with intermediate and advanced learners working in small bilingual teams to translate original new writing from Chinese to English or English to Chinese - with a small prize to the fastest team!
- afternoon 'editing fest' where you can review existing translations of Chinese texts on the Marco Polo website. This is a great opportunity for Mandarin beginners or writers with no prior experience in translation to better understand Chinese writing style and cross-cultural differences in articulating and organising ideas.
- panel discussion on translation and interpretation, bringing together industry professionals, writers and academics.
In parallel to these activities, there will be small reading and discussion groups on topics relative to contemporary China throughout the day. Participants are welcome to join for the whole day, or just come for a session or two.
To take part in translation and editing activities, please bring your own laptop or tablet.
This event is presented by the Marco Polo Project.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Macau Fringe Sound and Light Show
item.description:
Join in the colourful excitement of Macau Fringe 2014, a family event with a spectacular 3D light show and lots of entertainment.
Hosted by the Macau Government Tourist Office, this free six-day outdoor event will feature creative balloon artists, towering stilt walkers and other entertainment. Each night it will culminate in a three-dimensional projected show of the former Portuguese enclave's historic colonial and Chinese architecture – seen for the first time outside of Macau and China.
The nightly light show will focus on Macau's many UNESCO World Heritage-listed sites, from the famous A Ma Temple to the iconic ruins of St Paul's, the most highly photographed piece of architecture in Macau.
There will also be representatives from the Macau Government Tourist Office for anyone wanting information on planning a trip to Macau.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: Life's Lessons
item.description:
Calling all seniors! Do you have a story from your life that you would love to share? Have some fun learning how to use an iPad to tell it. Bring your own iPad (or borrow one of the library's), bring your story and learn how to record and edit it to share online.
This event is presented by Melbourne Library Service.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Limbo
item.description:
Limbo is a continuation of Miik Green's Xylem series, paintings that combine unlike materials that are sealed within layers of resin. Green draws his inspiration from the microscopic aspects of nature, and is involved in cross-disciplinary artistic collaborations.
Using mixed media on aluminium, Green creates translucent, colourful surfaces that seemingly capture movement in the momentary. Pigments, inks and resins are mixed with resistant media as diverse as liquid zirconia and thorium, creating structures that react and emerge within the surfaces of the works.
It is this paradoxical space, set between two extremes in which the work evolves: a site of conflict and tension where the cellular division of mitosis could also be seen as pathogenic replication.
In this process of intricate unconcealment, shapes take on an ambiguous clarity, appearing geographic and biological, dentritic and leguminous. The lustrous surfaces and colours that evolve both contain and encapsulate this tension and conflict, pausing movement in a limbo-like state. Here we see everything from the micro, the inner morphometry of the cellular, to the macro of cosmic array.

item.title: Lifelong Education for Sustainable Development
item.description:
For decades, international and national organisations have understood that lifelong learning is integral to enabling citizens to participate fully in civic and economic affairs. Yet there continues in all parts of the world to be little serious commitment to comprehensive policies for the implementation of lifelong learning. This is an important time to rethink how the policy agenda might be addressed as key international organisations debate the Sustainable Development Goals to replace the Millennium Development Goals which expire in 2015.
This workshop will enable members of the public to understand the gains made in the past 15 years, to review examples to constructive policy development, and to consider options for initiatives which could be proposed in relation to the Sustainable Development Goals.
This event is presented by the European Union Centre at RMIT University.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Kids Commission
item.description:
The Front's latest exhibition, Kids Commission by Keith Wong, will inspire and engage children of all ages. It features an interactive work involving milk dripping from the ceiling that will have you wondering if the gallery has sprung a leak!
There will be plenty to learn and discover for children and adults alike, as they encounter and partake in the activities of standing, counting, collecting, waiting and tasting.

item.title: Joint Clubs 125th Anniversary
item.description:
2014 marks the 125th Anniversary of both the Royal Park Tennis Club and the Princes Park Carlton Bowling Club. In this joint celebration and open day, everyone is invited to come and join in the fun. Have a hit of tennis and a game of bare foot bowls as the day progresses from the Tennis Club to the Bowling Club.
Celebrations begin at the Royal Park Tennis Club at 12pm when the club will open its doors for everyone to come and play tennis free of charge. Bring your own racquet and shoes or the club has them available for hire for a small fee. Enjoy afternoon tea before heading over to the bowling club at 4:30pm where you can take to the bowls rinks free of charge for a game of bare foot bowls.
The day has been designed to showcase both clubs, including their rich 125 years of history as well as the current services available for both members and guests. Along with the options of playing sports, each club will have food and cold beverages available for hungry visitors.

item.title: Jane Devery Lecture on the Manifesta 10 Biennale
item.description:
Hear a talk by Jane Devery, Curator of Contemporary Art at the National Gallery of Victoria, on her experience at Manifesta 10, the European Biennale of Contemporary Art, held in collaboration with the State Hermitage Museum, St Petersburg. Jane's participation in the St Petersburg-Melbourne 25th Anniversary Sister City Fellowship enabled her to attend the opening week of the Biennale.
The Biennale was a landmark opportunity to experience and learn more about the geopolitical history of the site and venues, along with various positions within contemporary art, in the company of the works of historical importance held in the Hermitage's collection.
This event is presented by the International Specialised Skills Institute as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: ISS Institute 24th Annual Fellowship Awards
item.description:
The International Specialised Skills Institute (ISS Institute) fellowships are designed to allow enterprising Australians to study innovations, technologies and best practice techniques overseas and bring these back to Australia. The program also brings international experts to Australia. This combination provides a unique approach to addressing the challenges faced by Australian industry in upskilling its workforce and remaining competitive in a changing global environment.
This event is brought to you by the International Specialised Skills Institute as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Is There a Future for Manufacturing in Australia?
item.description:
Challenges to the Australian manufacturing sector have never been greater. Increased global competition, technological innovation and a strong economy have threatened the existence of many Australian organisations. While these conditions may prove difficult for some firms, there remain many niche areas of operation and strategy in which Australian organisations can specialise to ensure they remain sustainably profitable and successful in the global market.
Improving the quality of leadership in Australian workplaces is often a neglected issue in the debate on competitiveness. This public lecture will investigate the role of leadership in shaping and driving Australia's transition to a high-value manufacturing economy. Keynote speaker John Pollaers, Chair of the Australian Advanced Manufacturing Council, will be joined by a panel of experts in a one-hour exploratory discussion of how leadership roles and techniques will impact the future of manufacturing in Australia.
John Pollaers has an extensive leadership background in the manufacturing sector, as the former Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director of Pacific Brands. John was Chief Executive Officer of Foster's Group Limited from May 2011, after joining the company as Managing Director of Carlton & United Breweries in 2010. John's distinguished career also encompasses experience in consumer products. His senior roles at Diageo plc included President Asia Pacific and Managing Director Australasia, where he was also a member of the Diageo Group Executive Committee. John's career has been marked by repeated turnaround performances in which he has successfully led nine business transformations, Pacific Brands' being the most recent.
This event is presented by the Centre for Workplace Leadership as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

ns0:venue.name: Sidney Myer Asia Centre, University of Melbourne

item.title: Is Out the New In? What’s Up with Outsider Art
item.description:
Forty years after the term Outsider Art was coined by Roger Cardinal to encompass works by untrained artists who work outside the established art world, new paradigms and definitions are being sought.
The night before the opening of Contemporary Outsider Art - A Global Context (an international conference mounted by Arts Project Australia and the University of Melbourne), join in this stimulating discussion about Outsider Art. Does it still deserve the name, or is it now an integral part of contemporary art?
Panellists include: - Dr Chris McAuliffe (MC) - Professor Lynne Cooke, Andrew W Mellon Professor at the National Gallery of Art, Washington, USA - James Brett, Founder, Museum of Everything - Professor Colin Rhodes, Dean, School of Fine Arts, The University of Sydney, founder of the Self-Taught and Outsider Art Collection (STOARC) at the University of Sydney and editor of Elsewhere, the International Journal of Self-Taught and Outsider Art.
This forum is supported by Future Leaders and Knowledge Melbourne, a City of Melbourne initiative.

item.title: How Stuff Gets to Melbourne
item.description:
Have you ever wondered what happens in the Port of Melbourne? Who works there, why the cranes are so big, or how we developed the waterways to bring the everyday goods we use to Melbourne?
Andrea Fleming (CEO, Mission to Seafarers) and John Bennett (General Manager, Bid Management, Port of Melbourne Corporation) will discuss the history, present and future of the value of the waterways.
This event is presented by the Mission to Seafarers and The Port of Melbourne Corporation.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Hack It
item.description:
Hack It is a unique workshop for high school students who want to turn their creative ideas into software and apps that can make a difference to the world.
Hack It will challenge students to create an app that solves a real problem facing the City of Melbourne. Whether you're an aspiring developer, social activist or entrepreneur, this is your chance to try coding for a day in a fun environment supported by researchers from NICTA and Melbourne universities. After a presentation setting the scene, you'll be split into assigned groups with a mix of different skills. Each group will brainstorm ideas, pick one to bring to life, create a demo and then pitch it to the full group and a panel of experts. The groups will be supported by NICTA researchers and software engineers, with prizes offered for the best pitch and best hack.
NICTA is Australia's largest information and communications technology (ICT) research and development centre. It pursues high-impact, original research that is inspired by real-world challenges. NICTA is also the national coordinating body for the Digital Careers program and a critical training ground for future ICT researchers.
This event is presented by NICTA and Digital Careers.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Grasslands
item.description:
Grasslands is a living installation that gathers over 10,000 indigenous plants. This organic composition aims to recreate the vast grass plains that stretched over the State Library of Victoria site before it was established in the mid-nineteenth century.
Linda Tegg conceived of this site-specific project during her 2012 Georges Mora Foundation Fellowship at the State Library of Victoria. Researching the original flora of this site, the artist found that most available data was interpretative, from Victorian landscape paintings to illustrated maps.
Looking to expand her sources of knowledge, Tegg collaborated with horticulturist John Delpratt and the University of Melbourne to source, grow and nurture the 10,000 indigenous plants and grasses that make up Grasslands.
The result is a transformation of history and nature by artistic imagination, inviting us to visualise the layers of memory and place.
This project has been assisted by the Australian Government through the Australia Council, its arts funding and advisory body and the Victorian Government through Arts Victoria. Grasslands has also been supported by the City of Melbourne through the Arts Grant Program.
This project is supported by University of Melbourne - Burnley Campus, Department of Resource Management and Geography. Grasslands is the result of a Georges Mora Foundation Fellowship at the State Library of Victoria.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: Going Virtual: The Arrival of the Internet
item.description:
It is a quarter-century since the University of Melbourne brought the Internet to Australia. At that time, it was seen as little more than a useful tool for computing professionals. So, what is the Internet?
A communications medium, a knowledge machine, a virtual universe? Professor Justin Zobel, Head of the University of Melbourne's Department of Computing and Information Systems, and a staff member in the Department during the years leading up to the Internet's arrival, will reflect on the Internet's evolution and impact. The talk will cover the concepts and ambitions that came together to create it to the emergence of an all-pervading technology that is dramatically changing - and challenging - how we work, play, learn, and think.
Professor Justin Zobel received his PhD from the University of Melbourne and for many years was based at RMIT University, where he led the Search Engine group. He is now Head of the Department of Computing and Information Systems at the University of Melbourne.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week.

item.title: Free Activities at Fitness First During Fitness Week
item.description:
Celebrate Fitness Week at Fitness First! Whatever your fitness level, come along and participate in a fantastic range of free daily themed activities, including group exercise classes, freestyle group training, workshops and advice.
Each day of Fitness Week will focus on a different area of fitness, from strength training and dynamic movement training to mind/body workshops involving Pilates and yoga, and the importance of recovery and wellness.

item.title: For King and Country
item.description:
East Melbourne Historical Society presents an exhibition commemorating the service of East Melbourne citizens in the First World War. Though only a small suburb, during the war there were over 770 service people with some connection - birth, work, housing - to East Melbourne.
This is one of the fun activities taking place across the City of Melbourne's library branches during History Week, 19 to 26 October.

item.title: Finding families
item.description:
Enter the intriguing world of genealogy and learn how to start building your family tree in this free introductory workshop for beginners.
Librarians from the Family History team will introduce the key principles of family history research, show you how to access and use a range of resources, and take you on a tour of the Library's Family History collection.

item.title: Exploring the Potentials of Virtual Reality
item.description:
Back in the '80s and '90s, Virtual Reality (VR) meant donning a headset and grasping at things that only you could see. VR as pure entertainment was the stuff of the super-gamer and was as limited in its appeal as its accessibility. In 2013, Oculus Rift released a headset available to the general consumer for under $500 and, not long after, Facebook acquired Oculus for $2billion.
Part of the unmasking of virtual reality has been its application to real-world needs - architectural walk-throughs, simulations, training - which is where the GEElab can show you the potentials of virtual reality. Join four GEElab experts and their guests as they take you through how (not) to build a VR game, how to use VR for architectural visualisation, serious games, and how to implement VR in Unity and Unreal Engine version 4. Games will also be playable at the session. Bookings essential.
This event is presented by RMIT University Games and Experimental Entertainment Lab (GEElab) as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Docklands History Group
item.description:
Travel back in time with local historians, collectors, guest speakers and meet like-minded people at the monthly Docklands History Group.
Share a cuppa and stories with other local history enthusiasts and learn about the people, places and industries from times gone by.
Join Special Guest Dr Judith Buckrich as she discusses the activities and lives of the people around Melbourne's docks, whose lives were characterised by bitter battles and political defiance underpinned by camaraderie, and who affected the history of the city in a way no other group has done.
The group meets on the fourth Thursday of the month and everyone is welcome.

item.title: Diwali at Library at The Dock
item.description:
Join in some fabulous activities to celebrate Diwali at Library at The Dock.
Take part in an Indian dance workshop, and bring your lunch for a picnic in the park. Make beautiful lamps out of paper and clay with your whole family.
Older children can participate in a maker's space workshop, and learn how to make a flashing greeting card with LED lights and electric paint.
Places are limited so book in now!

item.title: Dive into the Penguin Pool
item.description:
Named after Arup's first project - The Penguin Pool at London Zoo - this global creative event series aims to encourage new connections and seed future collaborations across the design community.
Arup is a leading design engineering firm that has played a key part in some of the world's finest and most famous buildings. From the Sydney Opera House to the Beijing Water Cube, Arup is a firm that continues to innovate within their discipline. Known for lateral thinking, they host The Penguin Pool annually to connect their firm with designers, creatives and artists.
The last Penguin Pool was held at Federation Square's Deakin Edge, with whom Arup collaborated with on the event. It asked artists to reimagine Melbourne and present work on how it might be improved. Four Melbourne Knowledge Week artists involved in past events, along with Arup, will share their thoughts and experiences collaborating with one another. Drinks and nibbles will be provided. Bring an open mind to new connections and ideas!
This event is presented by Arup.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.
Source: City of Melbourne What's On

item.title: Discover Sailing Day
item.description:
Discover Sailing is an initiative that gives people the opportunity to try sailing free of charge. Along with the assistance of Yachting Victoria, yacht clubs around the state will welcome the public to experience the joys of the sailing lifestyle.
In 2014/15, over 60 clubs will participate, exceeding the 2013/14 figure of 54 clubs.
Get down to the Docklands Yacht Club or a yacht club near you and give sailing a go.

item.title: Discover Europe Travel Expo
item.description:
The Discover Europe Travel Expo is in town, providing tips on exclusive deals for Europe-bound travellers looking to bag a bargain for a 2015 holiday.
The free expo offers expert advice, exclusive savings and everything travellers need to plan, compare and book under the one roof. Europe's leading travel providers and holiday specialists will unveil their earlybird offers and new products for 2015.
Participating airlines include Qantas, Malaysia and Singapore airlines, as well as tour operators including Trafalgar, Globus, APT, Topdeck, Scenic Tours, Contiki and Insight Vacations.
Experienced travel consultants from Flight Centre, Escape Travel, Student Flights and Cruiseabout will also be available to assist customers with their travel plans and take bookings on the day.

item.title: Designing Science
item.description:
Accurately designed biomedical animations can aid the understanding of researchers, displaying processes otherwise unseen by the human eye. 3D printers means rapid prototyping and ever-changing designs are easily incorporated.
In this panel discussion, explore design principles used in the animation of scientific knowledge to educate and entertain, in 3D titanium printing, molecule design and in science-inspired art.
This event is presented by CSIRO.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

ns0:venue.name: Australian Centre for the Moving Image (ACMI)

item.title: Contemporary Outsider Art Conference
item.description:
More than fifty artists, curators, educators and researchers from around the world will gather at the inaugural Contemporary Outsider Art Conference, presented by Arts Project Australia and the University of Melbourne, to discuss and debate the role and place of Outsider Art in a contemporary global context.
Since the late 19th century Outsider Art, also known as art brut or naive art, has referred to art made by the untrained or uneducated, those who exist outside the parameters of the traditional art world and, in particular, those who create art through the prism of mental illness, marginalisation or social exclusion.
The conference program of free keynote addresses, paper sessions and panel discussions will focus on the practices of Outsider Artists, collecting and curating Outsider Art and Outsider Art history and theory.
This conference is free and open to all.

item.title: Compass Market
item.description:
A day into the right, where brand new and unique individual artists, designers from Melbourne coming and showcasing together.
South meets North, East meets West.
Be sure to be widely entertained and inspired. From beautiful sound to your ear that will make you dance as you shop the very fine gifts from the collective creative beings. Amuse your wonder-last by our fashion catwalk, which will take place twice during the event.

item.title: Collaborative Knowledge Creation
item.description:
Join us to learn about collaboration as a tool to create new knowledge across social, industry and disciplinary boundaries - now and in the future.
Collabforge will explore methods of collaboration with 20-60 participants through a digitally-enhanced interactive workshop that demonstrates knowledge transfer and knowledge co-creation in real time. The session will be introduced and framed with a brief presentation of case studies from some of Collabforge's many knowledge-focused collaboration projects.
Presented by Collabforge.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: City Road – Melbourne's First Road Walking Tour
item.description:
Before European settlement, Melbourne's indigenous inhabitants walked a common path from the Yarra to the coast, arriving at what we now call Sandridge Beach. From 1835, Europeans followed this path which became known as Sandridge Road, Melbourne's first road. Today we know it as City Road.
Come along for a walk to learn the history of City Road, its importance, its industrial architecture, Melbourne's tallest buildings and the current City Road Master Plan.
This is one of the activities taking place across the City of Melbourne's library branches during History Week, 19-26 October.

item.title: Children's Week Art Exhibition
item.description:
The City of Melbourne's Children's and Family Services Team is celebrating Children's Week with an annual art exhibition, featuring inspiring artwork created by children and families attending City of Melbourne Children's Services and Family Services programs.
This year, Children's Services and Family Services will come together with a special art exhibition under the one theme: The right of the child to speak and be heard. The theme is taken from the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child.

item.title: Building the Future: New Manufacturing Business Breakfast
item.description:
Additive manufacturing is the new kid on the block in terms of manufacturing. Join MC Ticky Fullerton (The Business, ABC) and experts from RMIT University and CSIRO for breakfast at the RMIT Advanced Manufacturing Precinct. Hear about rapid product design and prototyping using state-of-the-art fabrication technologies such as electron beam melting for 3D printing of metals.
The RMIT Advanced Manufacturing Precinct houses some of the most advanced manufacturing technologies available, bringing design and engineering together, from digital design to digital manufacturing. The Precinct focuses in particular on 3D printing of advanced high value add products and components.
This event is presented by CSIRO, RMIT University and Inspiring Australia.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Bruno Leti – Landscapes of the Soul
item.description:
The Museo Italiano hosts an exhibition of Bruno Leti's work revisiting some fifty years of art-making.
Leti is represented in major Australian national, state and regional galleries and in public and private collections internationally. His art has also been the object of several monographs by leading art historians. Since his emigration from Italy in 1952, Bruno's Italianness has grown as an essential component of his artistic inspiration, nurtured by his childhood memories, by his studies in art history, by his frequent journeys to his native country and by an ongoing engagement with Italian art and literature.
Leti has travelled and worked widely in Europe, America and Asia, drawing inspiration from very diverse natural and cultural landscapes. Bruno describes himself as an Australian artist and indeed the multiculturalism and cosmopolitanism to which Bruno has made a signal contribution in the world of art, are by now quintessentially Australian traits.
The exhibition will be launched by Sir James Gobbo, and guest speaker Professor Sasha Grishin (Australian National University) will introduce the exhibition.

item.title: Boisterous Beginnings: Early Doctors in Victoria
item.description:
This exhibition examines the early beginnings of the Port Phillip Medical Association (PPMA),highlighting the key individuals and social values of the day.
From 1830s, doctors began their work in the Port Phillip District. There were some formidable personalities practising medicine in the area at the time, but they often had other interests and activities that were apparently more important: politics, for example, or the acquisition of land and the accumulation of fortune. This exhibition explores the people of this medical association.
This event is presented by the Medical History Museum.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Bilas Body Adornment
item.description:
Drawing upon body adornment techniques and designs from Pacific culture, visual artist Lisa Hilli works with particpants to create unique woven pieces to 'bilas' or adorn and decorate your body.
Utilising a mixture of contemporary everyday materials and Pacific weaving techniques, Lisa shares her passion and skill of weaving in a supportive studio environment.
This weaving workshop is aimed for young people aged 13 to 25 years. Previous weaving skills an advantage but not necessary.

item.title: Big Ideas Under the Dome: Elizabeth Broderick
item.description:
In this Big Ideas Under the Dome series lecture, Elizabeth Broderick, Australia's Sex Discrimination Commissioner, speaks on the status of gender equality in Australia. The 30-minute talk will be followed by Q&A with Jill Singer.
Elizabeth has acted as Sex Discrimination Commissioner since 2007, and was also the Commissioner responsible for Age Discrimination from 2007 to 2011. She has been a key advocate for Australia's national paid parental leave scheme and domestic violence reform, and is Global Co-Chair of the Women's Empowerment Principles Leadership Group, a joint initiative of the UN Global Compact and UN Women.

item.title: Big Bang Sounds
item.description:
How is new knowledge impacting the creative imaginations of today? This conversation will take you into the depths of the Big Bang and back again.
Lawrence Harvey, Associate Professor and Director SIAL Sound Studios, RMIT University, ventures into the unknown with Dr Katie Mack and artist Abel Korinsky to discuss new findings and theories related to the Big Bang. Can the Big Bang be seen and heard today? What place does it hold in scientific and artistic discourse?
Abel Korinsky from the Korinsky Art Collective (Germany) is currently in residence with Experimenta at RMIT Project Space, supported by EMARE (European Media Art Residency Exchange). Working with multichannel sound installations, Korinsky questions what could happen if sounds from the past could be reconstructed and hearable again.
Dr Katherine (Katie) Mack is a theoretical astrophysicist. Her work focuses on finding new ways to learn about the early universe and fundamental physics using astronomical observations, probing the building blocks of nature by examining the cosmos on the largest scales.
This event is presented by Experimenta.
Part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: Be a Composer!
item.description:
Join this three-day interactive music composition and performance workshop with Ben Opie, Melissa Doecke and Phoebe Green. The workshops culminate in a piece that is developed with participants throughout the week. Learn about the creative process, new techniques, commissioning new works and collaborating with artists.
Join Inventi Ensemble in this rare opportunity to learn about music performance and create a new piece of music, to be performed live as part of the Acoustica series at Melbourne City Library. Ben Opie, Melissa Doecke and Phoebe Green will lead discussions on their experience of commissioning new works, arranging existing compositions and interpreting extant works.
As part of these workshops, Inventi Ensemble members will perform pieces that can demonstrate some of the many techniques they use to express themselves through music.
Participants will learn about pushing the boundaries of musical instruments and how to use these techniques in the process of creating a piece of music. Inventi Ensemble will guide you in how new works are created, ranging from improvisation to interpretation to graphic scores.
Musical knowledge and music reading skills are not required - just come along with your creative ideas and explore how they can be translated into music. All you need is your imagination and enthusiasm!
This event is presented by Inventi Ensemble and Acoustica as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: AURIN Urban Mapping Workshop
item.description:
Explore data about Melbourne's suburbs and Australia's cities in this Melbourne Knowledge Week workshop.
During this workshop you will extract information using the sophisticated tools contained within the Australian Urban Research Infrastructure Network (AURIN) portal, so you can mould this information into visualisable and sharable knowledge. Until now, much of this information has remained behind closed doors. AURIN enables access to this data for built environment professionals across all fields, letting users discover and mash-up data, information and knowledge.
Participants will undertake exercises in studying health data, visualising walkability of neighbourhoods and more. Knowledge of these issues is essential to understanding patterns of urban development, to form and model urban growth for a sustainable future.
This event is presented by the Australian Urban Research Infrastructure Network as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014.

item.title: A Melbourne Boston Knowledge Exchange
item.description:
You are invited to discover the reputation Melbourne and Boston share as world-leading knowledge cities.
Join leaders with a passion for knowledge for a special cocktail reception during Melbourne Knowledge Week, including the official announcement of the 2014 Hugh Rogers Fellows, a showcase of the 2013 Hugh Rogers Fellows and their experiences in both cities, and an opportunity to network and connect with other leaders passionate about Melbourne and Boston.
The showcase of 2013 Hugh Rogers Fellows MBSCA will feature the important contribution being made by past Hugh Rogers Fellows, with a panel discussion where 2013 recipients will share information about the research and projects undertaken in the past year in Boston. Find out how their fellowship experiences have enhanced the reputation of Melbourne and Boston as centres of knowledge excellence, as well as their own field of work internationally and locally within their institutions in Melbourne.
The showcase will include four inspiring female Melbourne knowledge leaders: Dr Lauren Ayton, Centre for Eye Research Australia (City of Melbourne Fellow, Healthcare & Medical Research); Ms Christine Healey, Heide Museum of Modern Art (Education); Dr Rebecca Lim, The Ritchie Centre, Monash Institute of Medical Research (Healthcare & Medical Research); and Ms Gemma Turvey, The New Palm Court Orchestra (The Arts and Culture).
Attendees will have the opportunity to pose questions to the 2013 Hugh Rogers Fellows and discover more about their work and experiences being a part of this Melbourne Boston knowledge exchange.
As part of Melbourne Knowledge Week, MBSCA will officially announce recipients of the 2014 Hugh Rogers Fellowships in the areas of healthcare, medical research and biotechnology, education, and the arts and culture.
This event is presented by the Melbourne Boston Sister Cities Association as part of Melbourne Knowledge Week.

item.title: Annual Gerard Crock Lecture
item.description:
The Centre for Eye Research Australia (CERA) invites you to the 2014 Annual Gerard Crock Lecture, on the topic: Future challenges for managing glaucoma.
Presented by Professor Jonathan Crowston, CERA Managing Director Ringland Anderson Professor of Ophthalmology University of Melbourne, the lecture will be introduced by the Hon David Davis MP, Victorian Minister for Health.
This public lecture honours the memory and contribution of Professor Gerard Crock AO (1929-2007), inaugural Ringland Anderson Professor of Ophthalmology.

item.title: Marysville Art Show
item.description:
The premier event on the regional arts calendar the Marysville Arts Show is on again over the Melbourne Cup Weekend with a grand opening night on October the 31st.
The theme of this years show is Great Art by Great Artists and the exhibition showcases local and regional Artists. The exhibition is being held in the Marysville Community Centre in Falls road Marysville and is open to all. Monies raised from the Art Show go to support local arts projects.
The opening night is shaping up as the not to be missed night of the year. Come along and meet the Artists, see and buy the wonderful works and be entertained as well. Special guest at the opening is bush poet and raconteur Jim Brown who will be reciting some of his poignant works themed around the ANZACs and Marysville after the fires. Music will be provided by talented local musicians on harp, fiddle, pipes and pans. The whole community and local businesses have come together to host this event.
Judging this year's event is renowned artist Max Wilkes. Max will judge the first prize, being the $1500 Murrindindi Shire Award, second the Gould memorial prize as well as Triangle Real Estate and the local business awards. Patrons and visitors will have their chance to judge the works in the People Choice Award.
The talented local VCE students have been given the opportunity to exhibit some of their works in the emerging artists section. Works from Artists on Acheron will also be on display. Another feature of this years show is the Children's section to be judged by Lenny the Leadbeater's possum. This event will be judged on the Saturday morning at the Children's exhibition space.

item.title: Children's Week at Numurkah Library
item.description:
Come and join in with the Rhymes, Songs and Crafts session from 10.30 to 11.30am at the Numurkah Library during Children's Week.
This free activity will have a show theme to support the Numurkah Agricultural Show to be held the following day. This activity is open to all children and is a great way to spend the morning

item.title: Children's Week at Cobram Library
item.description:
All children are encouraged to join the Cobram Library and receive a free book during Children's Week! The first fifty children to join the Cobram Library in Children's Week will receive a fabulous free book to encourage and develop a love for reading.
Children who are already members of the library and visit during Children's Week will be entered in a raffle to win book prizes.

item.title: Children's Week in Mount Beauty
item.description:
Join Jill Parkes as she tells the tale of Ella Kazoo and her unruly hair during Children's Week from 10am to 11am.
Ella Kazoo would rather do anything than brush her hair, especially when she could be skipping in the rain and dancing in the sunshine instead. As her hair grows from bad to worse, soon it's out of control! Something be done to tame her wild locks.

item.title: Children's Week in Bright
item.description:
Join Jill Parkes as she tells the tale of Ella Kazoo and her unruly hair during Children's Week from 10am to 11am.
Ella Kazoo would rather do anything than brush her hair, especially when she could be skipping in the rain and dancing in the sunshine instead. As her hair grows from bad to worse, soon it's out of control! Something be done to tame her wild locks.

item.title: McClelland Sculpture Survey & Award 2014
item.description:
Since its inception in 2003, the McClelland Sculpture Survey & Award has emerged as the most important biennial outdoor sculpture exhibition in Australia. The exhibition presents 35 works in an outdoor exhibition that highlights the diversity and invention of contemporary sculpture.
The 34 finalists will be eligible for the acquisitive McClelland Award of $100,000.00 for outdoor sculpture, the McClelland Achievement Prize (MAP) of $30,000 which also includes a solo exhibition at McClelland and the Frankston City People's Choice Award of $20,000.
The winner of the McClelland Award and the McClelland Achievement Prize will be announced on Sunday 23 November 2014.
Dr Liz Kreijin, Assistant Director Collection and Presentation, Kröller-Müller Museum, Netherlands will judge the McClelland Award 2014.
The Kröller-Müller Museum is internationally recognised as one of the world's premier Sculpture Parks, set on over 25 hectares, it displays over 170 objects including works by Marta Pan, Jean Dubuffet, Richard Serra, Atelier van Lieshout, Chris Booth and Jan Fabre.
The McClelland Sculpture Survey & Award was established in 2003 and quickly established itself as the most influential and prestigious exhibition of outdoor public sculpture in Australia. It brings together a wide range of sculptors from emerging, mid-career and established artists, working in wide range of styles and different media. It truly encapsulates the best of current sculpture practice. The 34 selected Survey sculptures will be displayed along a picturesque sculpture trail which winds its way through a variety of natural bush landscape and grasslands making it both an art and nature experience.
The McClelland Sculpture Survey & Award is proudly supported by The Balnaves Foundation and the Elisabeth Murdoch Sculpture Fund.

item.title: Children's Week in Myrtleford
item.description:
Join Jill Parkes as she tells the tale of Ella Kazoo and her unruly hair during Children's Week from 10am.
Ella Kazoo would rather do anything than brush her hair, especially when she could be skipping in the rain and dancing in the sunshine instead. As her hair grows from bad to worse, soon it's out of control! Something be done to tame her wild locks.

item.title: Yang Fudong: Filmscapes
item.description:
Filmscapes is Australia's largest-ever survey of China's pre-eminent moving-image artist, Yang Fudong, showing at the Australian Centre for the Moving Image (ACMI).
Chinese artist Yang Fudong has firmly established himself as one of the world's most extraordinary moving-image artists. His work's lyrical and dreamlike qualities, long and suspended sequences, spiraling narratives and multiple perspectives reflect the psychology of a new generation as it struggles to find its place in present-day China.
Stylistically rooted in Chinese painting, Yang Fudong's multi-channel film installations also reflect a fascination with international cinema, and in particular, film noir.
ACMI also presents a one-off screening of Yang's epic Seven Intellectuals in a Bamboo Forest (2003-2007), which is the first time that all five parts of this landmark film have been presented end-to-end in a cinema.
Yang Fudong is represented by ShanghART Gallery, Shanghai, and Marian Goodman Gallery, New York.
Yang Fudong: Filmscapes is presented as part of ACMI's special summer season China Up Close.

ns0:venue.name: Australian Centre for the Moving Image (ACMI)

item.title: Community Health Expo
item.description:
This Community Health Expo has grown out of the vision of a few local residents who want to make sure their community feels supported after recent traumatic events including the grass fires. Everyone is invited. It is a free event and supper will be provided.
This is not a fire readiness expo but rather an opportunity for everyone who lives in the Sunbury, Riddles Creek, Darraweit Guim, Romsey, Kilmore, Wallan areas to gather, share stories and understand the services out there and how they work together to keep our families and property safe.
The event will be both an expo of service providers displaying and discussing what services they can offer us. There will also be a host of fantastic speakers show casing innovative local practices and achievements helping to make our community safer, stronger, more resilient and better prepared to manage any emergency situation.
Time: 5pm to 9pm

item.title: Childrens week: Talk about it morning tea
item.description:
Cobaw Children's Services are taking part in Children's Week by holding a 'Talk about it' morning tea for families with young children.
The event will be hosted by Speech Pathologists Naomi Mc Craw and Fiona Whitmee and is free to all families living in the Macedon Ranges. They will provide ideas on how to encourage and stimulate your child's development through games, songs, play and rhyming fun and a range of interesting activities for both children and parents to engage with.
Time: 10.45 to 11.45am.

item.title: Early Years Programs
item.description:
The Early Years programs at St Georges Road Primary School in Shepparton provide fun and engaging activities for children aged 0 to 5 years and families to play, develop and grow in a supportive and friendly environment.
The programs include:
- Run, Hop, Jump, Play - Active fun for all on Mondays from 9:15 - Sensory Play - Exploring the senses through engaging (and messy!) play on Tuesdays from 9:15 - Mothergoose - Rhymes, stories and songs to share, Wednesdays at 9:15 - Paint and Play - All sorts of fun on Thursdays at 9:15.
All programs are free and run every week during school terms.
The St George Road Primary School hope to see you there soon!

item.title: Wyndham Diwali Mela - Victorian Multicultural Festival of Lights
item.description:
Diwali is a very widely anticipated festival, it's a unique phenomenon is occurring where the festival is now being celebrated by most communities in the Western suburbs of Melbourne.
This year celebrate the festival with wonderful art forms at display, with greater community groups performing on stage with their various talents.
The Festival picked up a great pace last year, thanks to your patronage dear readers who visited in great numbers throughout the day, reaching over 10,000.
The laurels of last year's celebrations has reached many community groups and has attracted more enthusiasm from African, European, North American, Asian, Pacific and many other descendants to join us.
The Diwali Festival of Lights is now taking place over a larger area and the organisers hope all your friends come and have a big picnic on the day, ending with fireworks. The variety in nationalities performing on the stage has grown to a good number.
Come join the Diwali celebrations at the Presidents' Park in the central region of Werribee and Hoppers Crossing in close vicinity to many upcoming suburbs such as Wyndham Vale, Tarneit, Truganina, Williams Landing, etc.
The land is vast this time for all the patrons coming to the festival all through the day. The kids have a great outing near the vicinity of the stage so that entire family can enjoy the quality entertainment. The festivals partnership base has grown this year to have more number of participants on stage.
If you are in a radius of 15 kilometres of Werribee, please drop by for a special celebration of the coming together of cultures at the event.

item.description:
Longford Lions Christmas Parade and Market will take place on Saturday 6 December 2014, 8.00am to 1.00pm.
The Market will start at Brennan Park Sale at 8.00 am and the Street Parade will commence at 10.00 am at The St. Columbus Car Park continuing along Raymond Street finishing at Brennan Park, where Santa will be arriving. At 12.00 the Sale - Maffra Toy run will be arriving.

item.description:
Stratford Primary School is hosting their annual Spring Fete.
There will be a Fantastic Scarecrow competition with some great prizes.

item.description:
Bring your family and friends and participate in the Gippsland Art Gallery's biggest community event of the year!
This initiative is part of the International Campaign for Drawing with over twenty countries participating and you are invited to join artist-facilitated workshops throughout the Gallery, Sale Library, Entertainment Centre, Aqua Energy and Sale Botanic Gardens.
This year's Big Draw theme, It's Our World, is a celebration of our environment - of urban, rural and coastal landscapes.
At the Gippsland Art Gallery enjoy drawing with guest artists Ali Fullard, Claire Marston and Michelle The Big Draw 2014
To celebrate children's week, the Big Draw will be hitting the road 20-24 October as part of the Messy Play Roadshow supported by Wellington Shire Council and Uniting Care Gippsland.

item.title: Guest Cellar Door at Barwite Vineyard
item.description:

Special prices just for you and your Christmas table. Luncheon platters will also be available prepared by Ben Davies from the Culinarian. Come along and enjoy the day and bring your friends Bookings for lunch are recommended.

item.title: Talbot Farmers Market
item.description:
On the third Sunday every month the Talbot Farmers' Market comes alive as thousands of visitors enjoy the vibrant village atmosphere.
Explore an evolving display of over 80 regional produce stalls, including seasonal fruit and organic vegetables, local artisan cheese, fresh bread, local wine, gourmet oils, delicious delicacies and more. In true country farmers' market style you will also find pigs, goats and chooks, stockfeed, cut flowers, plants and seedlings.
Sample fabulous food and wine, enjoy a coffee and a tasty bite to eat while listening to local artists playing live music in the street.
Pick up a ticket for your chance to win the 'Barrow Raffle' overflowing with wonderful produce kindly donated by our stall holders.
Remember to bring your shopping bags or grab a gorgeous calico bag from the information marquee.
Browse for unexpected treasures at the adjacent Town Hall Market.
Talbot is just 40 minutes north of Ballarat or 90 minutes from Melbourne's Westgate Bridge.

item.title: Sports Boat and PWC Expo
item.description:
Just a two hour drive from Melbourne, Bonnie Doon, on the banks of Lake Eildon, is the new home of the Sports Boat and PWC Expo for 2014.
The two day event is a free event, to be held in conjunction with the Lake Eildon Festival. With boat displays both off, and on the water, this is your chance to really check out Australia's best sports boats from the ground up and then head out on the lake to see what they are like floating.
There will be professional wakeboard and waterski demos throughout the weekend world-champion coaching opportunities, boat license testing and plenty of entertainment for both young and old. The Bonnie Doon Hotel will be hosting the event, making meals, snacks, and refreshments, readily available to get your hands on throughout the weekend.
Keep an eye on their Facebook page for the latest.

item.title: Smart Cities with Digital Skins: What will this mean for you?
item.description:
The internet of things and smart technology is already impacting the way everyone understands and uses cities.
Hear how sensors are changing everyone's lives and how everyone uses and manages metadata.
Will 'smart cities' deliver greater economic and public good? What about liveability and privacy?
Held during Melbourne Knowledge Week 2014 and MC'd by ABC Radio National's Antony Funnell, this event features Deakin University's Chief Digital Officer, William Confalonieri among other leading industry experts.

item.title: British Heraldry of the Great War
item.description:
This lecture, largely illustrated with images from the records of the College of Arms, will discuss the representation of the Great War in the armorial bearings granted to various military and naval commanders, armament manufacturers and others. The arms will be set in the context of older English heraldic traditions. The heraldic consequences of George V's desire to sever his family's ties with Germany will also be discussed.
The lecture will be presented by David Vines White and be held in the Auditorium, Education Centre at the Shrine of Remembrance
The event is free but gold coin donation welcome.

image.altText: British Heraldry of the Great War
British Heraldry of the Great War
